review_content:
(2025 Edition)

Opens fresh, clean, citrusy and green, with the smokiness of the Keemun opening up within minutes, tannic flavour and a slight ineffable fruitiness beginning to pour out. The green tea facets soon follow, and actually come across more authentic than in the majority of blends I’ve seen it in. It’s that particular grassy, earthy astringency that’s actually quite difficult to accurately capture. Jasmine, honeysuckle and honeybush are also conveyed beautifully, creating a delectable honeyed, floral jasmine & black tea combination with a deep woody boost from below.

In about an hour the base begins to unveil, robust, woody cedar and earthy, spiced Chinese oud perfectly supporting the teas in the heart. Sandalwood isn’t terribly prominent to me now but may arise later in the drydown as is common to it. I also have difficulty determining what spices adorn the base, but I think there might be a hint of something faintly musky, perhaps cumin, and also maybe some caraway. There have also been some very slight rubbery nuances from the honeybush in the heart, but I think they actually accentuate the woody and smokiness of the oud and black tea very properly.

Becomes all the more resinous in the drydown while retaining much of the great citric and tannic properties. Sandalwood as expected does appear to help smooth things out in the final act. All in all, I actually consider this a stupendous blend, a super easy and fun tea-and-oud scent that even newcomers will find bewitching & fascinating. Best worn in spring and summer but would personally make occasional exceptions during the colder months as well.

Sillage moderate to strong, longevity excellent. At $135/30mL through American Perfumer, it’s a bit on the pricier side but I’d definitely consider it justified.

Bravo, good sir!!!

review_title: And it smells good, by the way
review_content:
Kenzo has a great sense of humour, if you ask me. And if I translate the name of this fragrance correctly: Ça sent Beau meaning This smells good. What a great name for a perfume! But apart from being quite fun, there is a truth to it, that I shall have to comment on. Since with this astounding product I do sometimes consider the smell secondary. Perhaps that needs an explanation. Let us look at in what order this unfolds itself.
It starts with the wrapping: stunning. The EdP comes in a beautiful light green box with a beautiful black (hand) writing stating Kenzo. Next to this is a red seal like decoration, a Japanese ‘hanko’. The box has structures of leaves pressed into the cardboard. Inside, the bottle is wrapped in crisp peach coloured tissue paper, almost nesting in it. Oh yes please! Now, that is what I call decent wrapping. The whole act of unwrapping makes my nervous system go bonkers. So much, that I tend to forget what it is all about - the fragrance.
But then there is the bottle. I have the deodorant, the miniature EdT and the ‘real thing’ - the EdP. All are in the stunning category. The EdP, however, takes the price. It has a stopper shaped like two flowers, and the neck and bottle reminds me of the now again popular activity of stacking rocks on top of each other. Even though the top is plastic, the whole picture is a balanced, beautiful and bold design, that leaves me with a luxurious feeling. So much that I tend to forget what it is all about - the fragrance.
Well, the fragrance is out of this world and should be in the Top100 - despite its high ranking, it is not in Parfumo’s Women’s Top100, which surprises me. It is creamy, floral and soapy at the same time. When it warms up it has a floral expression that makes me want it to stay like that forever. Actually, I think it is timeless. Such a shame that it is discontinued. But then again, I get to enjoy it, because it is in my collection.
Year 2, 158/365

Today, I wanted to compare the Ça Sent Beau EAU DE TOILETTE on the right and left arms with the "Ça Sent Beau / Kenzo (Eau de Parfum) | Kenzo." To my surprise, the perfume lasts only 3-4 hours on my skin with a rather weak sillage. The Eau de Toilette comes across as much more concentrated, likely due to its age - both fragrances come from collection dissolutions and are in older miniature bottles. I find the DNA of the scent not too bad but also a bit old school. It smells very floral and fruity.

The top note starts fruity with peach but also floral-sweet with orange and jasmine blossoms. The heart note remains distinctly floral. I detect rose water, geraniums, tuberose, gardenias, iris, violets, and lily of the valley - what a sea of flowers! The base reminds me a bit of soap and fabric softener. Additionally, I recognize a green-earthy patchouli aroma. It also has a slightly vanillic and balsamic scent.

All in all, this is a fairly successful fragrance, but I wouldn't necessarily associate it with my "dream woman," as I find it a bit outdated.

EDIT 23.02.2024: Now I have tested another miniature. Here, the longevity was significantly better at around 12 hours. In the top note, I also detected bergamot and a jam-like quality. As it develops further, it also smells quite oriental, festive, and of cinnamon.

review_title: A Mild Pineapple Fart in the Tuscan Wind
review_content:
How can I resist the temptation when the price of an EdC is under €3 / 100 ml? Especially since it's supposed to be one of the much-touted Barbershop classics.

I've always wondered which target group this ominous Lustray line is aimed at, as Pinaud Clubman offers very solid drugstore products for the US market at a (there) very low price. Lustray is - in my impression - the budget version of the house and can even be ordered in canister sizes in case of a major emergency. My expectations are initially at 0, just like a meat hedgehog on the party buffet. It's also old school, rosy, and just as unappealing as the plastic bottle.

Bottle: see above. Unappealing! I have nicer things in the garage or tool shed. But one must not be deterred by the Pinaud / Lustray bottles, otherwise one might miss out on one or another gem. They remind me of discount beer bottles like those from Lidl. Horribly made and exclusively made of plastic, which I actually wanted to ban from my household for ethical reasons.

Longevity: Here I would be at the heading. So disappointingly mild and flat-chested, at best on the level of an aftershave. Measurable in minutes.

Sillage: Was there something? Even for the highly sensitive noses of my cats, I remain almost invisible in terms of scent. Also for my two-legged golden treasure. Even for myself.

Scent: Fresh pineapple briefly tossed in Provençal herbs and doused with a hint of musk. Good. Solid. Simple. Proven.

Conclusion: In the main subject a 2, otherwise only 5s and 6s on the report card. That’s not enough for promotion. Class goal missed.

review_title: Should I watch while your perfumes worship the sun?? :D
review_content:
Hello you sun-worshipping perfumes (who are surely hating the cold days right now!). Soo… oh man, I wish I hadn't started with "sun-worshipping," because now I have… strange thoughts… like imagining you in bikinis, let’s say, in alluring movements worshipping the sun, which surely catches the fleeting glance of us guys *sigh*
It's kind of like when you do yoga (oh my God… some of those poses make your heart stop!! Who came up with such "exercise positions" like "Downward Dog" or even "Merudandasana" or whatever it's called (the one where you spread your legs so extremely)… Arrrrghghgh :DD Not to mention many other "positions"!!…

Anyway, how did I come to sun worshippers? Quite simple: The fragrance here is called "Sympathy for the Sun" (by Roos & Roos/Dear Rose). And I think, especially you ladies must love the sun much more than men, right? Well, I’m not a big fan of the sun. Yes, yes, because I’m single and blah blah, we've been through that several times… no, this time I wanted to say that the sun can be beautiful, but all those heat waves in summer really annoy me. A few years ago it was okay, there were just a few hot days, but now it looks like the heat waves are increasing and lasting longer… anyway, I just don’t like extreme heat and I already feel sick thinking about next summer *sigh* No sorry… I much prefer winter! :)

Anyway, I’ll get to the scent, which sounds quite fresh :)

The scent:
The scent has a rather classic opening with citrus and oak moss and even briefly resembles an aftershave or those scents found in barbershops. But don’t worry, just a minute later the scent becomes distinctly more feminine with sweet jasmine and roses. Of course, the classic touch from the oak moss remains, but this classic note doesn't come across as much like a men's aftershave anymore :D
Over time, the scent loses much of its citrus freshness and becomes more powdery-sweet, but not in an overwhelmingly intense way, so it still stays light and breezy.
Now many seem to smell salt here, but I find the salt to be rather subtle. Especially towards the end, the scent is, as mentioned, more sweet and powdery, with a hint of woodiness. The sweetness mainly comes from the jasmine and is generally floral and soft, but occasionally reminds me a little of tonka bean.
All in all, a very nice scent.

The sillage and longevity:
The sillage is weak, as one is used to from summer scents or fresh fragrances. This one at least stands out a bit through the bitter oak moss now and then, but even then the scent is relatively weak overall. I found the longevity to be average, around five to six hours. Especially for summer, this is quite good.

The bottle:
The bottle is rectangular with nice curves… uh, I meant with strongly rounded corners :D On the front, you see a golden label with the name of the fragrance. The neck is gilded and bears the brand name engraved in it. The cap is black and cylindrical. Everything is quite okay, but not incredibly exciting.

Okay, that was "Sympathy for the Sun." And even though I extremely hate the sun during heat waves, I must say that this scent turned out to be all the more beautiful, even if I shouldn't like the name of the fragrance right now :D

But honestly, the scent is not really refreshing, yet it is still light and breezy despite the sweet notes. It is soft with powdery undertones, sweetly delicious with sweet scents like jasmine, and has a slightly spicy-bitter base reminiscent of woody notes and tonka. It fits wonderfully into spring and summer with its beautiful, light aura and can be used as a daytime scent, for work, and even for going out on warm days, as it also comes across as elegant, even though it could have been a bit stronger for going out.

In my opinion, this scent is definitely very recommendable, even if it may seem quite simple in terms of scent progression. So, give it a try; it can make you feel soft, cute, and elegant, maybe even delicious :D But please don’t wear it to yoga or while… well… sun-worshipping… or else guys like me might just drop dead from heart failure… waaaah!!!
But okay, enough about my dirty fantasies, well, at least for this comment here, he he :DDD

Well then, take care and have a nice evening :)

...this fragrance is pleasant to wear.

Upon spraying, one gets a light apple note even though it is not listed in the fragrance pyramid. This is complemented by the freshness of mint and citrus fruits. A very slight spiciness is emitted by the juniper berry. The thyme further emphasizes the spicy note, followed by a woody note.

The longevity and sillage are below average.

This fragrance can be worn for any occasion in summer.

The perfume is no longer in production.

This opens with a blast of clean solar aldehydes paired with some fresh aromatic sage. Then you get an almost bubblegummy powdery sweetness paired with some creamy warm florals. The citrus here reads like a soapiness but not in a cleaning products way, more so like clean laundry. This feels like a desert haze, a mirage even. It’s hard to describe what this really smells like but it’s such an alluring smell. The dry down reads more floral with a prominent linden blossom paired with some ambery warmth.

This opens with a blast of clean solar aldehydes paired with some fresh aromatic sage. Then you get an almost bubblegummy powdery sweetness paired with some creamy warm florals. The citrus here reads like a soapiness but not in a cleaning products way, more so like clean laundry. This feels like a desert haze, a mirage even. It’s hard to describe what this really smells like but it’s such an alluring smell. The dry down reads more floral with a prominent linden blossom paired with some ambery warmth.

Hello everyone,

Today I want to talk about a very, very special and unfortunately too rare EO, the "Kambodi Gris (Eau de Parfum) | Ensar Oud / Oriscent".

A little general information:

There are 2129 Rose - Oud fragrances from the company (number fictional, but feels true^^), x smoky, x green, xx musky beasts - but nothing that you can really wear all the time = unproblematic, pleasant, doesn't clash. I know how some think about this, and I partially agree, BUT there are also days when you might not want to hear certain comments about what you're wearing, and that's when the "Kambodi Gris (Eau de Parfum) | Ensar Oud / Oriscent" comes into play.

Because it is pleasant, unproblematic, doesn't clash, is ultra high quality, you feel special, etc.

How does it smell:

The actual main character here is the ambergris, BUT it is different (!). Ambergris usually has an aquatic - mineral - smoky impression like, for example, in EO normal, whether it’s "Black Gris | Ensar Oud / Oriscent", "Gris Sultani | Ensar Oud / Oriscent", or "Jamaican Ambergris Attar | Ensar Oud / Oriscent". Here, the smoky component is, in my opinion, almost 100% eliminated.

It feels very Western and almost not like a fragrance from EO, because it is very easy to wear.

For every season, every possible occasion!

Are there similarly scented fragrances?

Yes and no.

What comes closest to the "Kambodi Gris (Eau de Parfum) | Ensar Oud / Oriscent" is the V: Amber Fougere, HOWEVER this is not a fougere fragrance, it has no pepper, no sweetness - nothing.

The included lavender and rose are a very high-quality accompaniment, but nothing more, and the included Cambodian oud forms its woody foundation and, in my opinion, is perfectly balanced.

The sillage is perfectly sufficient, and it effortlessly handles a normal workday.

If there were a 50 ml bottle, I would grab it because I am quite enthusiastic about it. It is this pleasantly understated, always fitting - like a tailored suit.

If the opportunity arises = test it!

And now have a nice day/evening or whenever you read this review, best regards, Benny
_______

The lovely comments here have once again triggered a "want-to-have" reflex since I really enjoy powdery vanilla scents. Snagged blindly in the souk from a dear perfumer, I went straight to testing today.
Hmm... Vanilla? I don't smell it at all... but first, a green-almond note. I actually quite like it here after overcoming the initial shock of the non-vanilla :)
The vanilla doesn't really come through on my skin at first. That's okay... I like almonds too. This almond note is so beautiful, delicate, and powdery. I'm thrilled. Slowly, after about an hour, the vanilla starts to make an appearance.
Cara is a powdery scent dream made of beautiful almond milk surrounded by gentle vanilla. Not at all intrusive, not too sweet because that green feeling, wherever it may come from, is always present.
Cara is truly a fine fragrance that gently envelops the wearer in a delicate scent veil. Unisex... I don't think so... in my opinion, Cara is too feminine for that.
Of course, I also wanted to know where the almond comes from. In ALZD, the fragrance pyramid is displayed a bit differently... and so the overall picture fits :)
For those interested:
Top note: Vanilla, Sugar
Heart note: Almond, Caramel
Base note: Amber, Powdery Notes
Unfortunately, I can't provide exact information about the longevity, but sprayed 3 hours ago, the scent still smells very intense. The sillage isn't that great... but it doesn't have to be... here it suffices to feel a sense of satisfaction from this wonderful fragrance. I can imagine wearing Cara in any season.
The bottle... well, beautiful is something else, but the content matters.
Conclusion: Cara is beautiful! I'm glad to have her in my fragrance collection!

Today, Cara moved in with me.
It was a rather spontaneous decision, as I had sworn to live alone from now on, for reasons.
Things turned out differently, and I am glad about it.
Cara is simply wonderful.
She doesn't like to be in the spotlight, yet she is hard to overlook.
She appreciates understatement, and that is precisely what makes her so appealing.
She comes on quiet feet and enchants with her lightness more than many crowd-pleasers that shout "Make way!" from 10 meters away.
Cara wraps you around her finger without you even noticing, and before you know it, she has come to stay.
Resolutions are made to be broken, so I gladly made room for Cara beside me.

Cara?

CARA???

Oh there you are, hmmmm……

This comment is dedicated to my "scent sister" AnnaKi :-)

Cara...the world's most beautiful vanilla scent!

Delicious, airy, and soaring it is, "uplifting" like the golden rays of the sun, it surrounds me like liquid happiness.

It is hard to put into words because something very special defines it; how can I do it justice? It is different from all other vanilla scents.

Sweet yet light, it has a pronounced caramel note that doesn’t feel heavy and still shows a lot of presence. The almond is more like almond milk dusted with the finest powder.

Although a gourmand with plenty of sillage and longevity, it remains as light as a golden vanilla kiss from an angel. A delicate creaminess like a spread cake batter is added; all of this is always very sweet but never too sweet. It must be the amber that ensures it is and remains an adult gourmand.

It radiates carefreeness and an inner sunshine... "I am 8 years old and ride my bike home from school, today it ends early, I am so happy. In the warm summer air, butterflies flutter, my fingers brush past golden ears of corn along the roadside, the wind gently caresses my face... when I arrive home, my mother sets a bowl of still warm vanilla pudding with caramel sauce on the table, outside the birds are chirping, life is so beautiful"...
This feeling is what Cara transports for me.

The only question remains why on earth it is not yet in my collection;-)

The Cara is beautiful.
The Cara makes you happy.
The Cara invites you to feel good.
The Cara is very clingy.
The Cara is sweet and powdery and soft.
The Cara takes me mentally through a high summer wildflower meadow in the morning, where the incredibly wonderful vanilla combines with the scent of the wild meadow for many, many hours.
The Cara is different from other vanilla fragrances, with a subtler sweetness that never overwhelms.
The Cara is sunny, blissful vanilla with powdered sugar and more summery than any other perfume.
The Cara is an absolute dream that I always love to have by my side.

I have to agree with Sunshine - a sweet, angelic almond note garnished with vanilla sugar to comfort on dark and cold days. One wants to throw on their cozy tracksuit and then disappear under the blanket on the couch or in bed with the scent on their skin :)

The fragrance is sweet - but not cloyingly sweet. You can't directly smell the amber, but I think it’s exactly this hint that keeps the scent balanced so it doesn’t drift into girly sweetness. Thus, it remains a cozy scent for the adult woman or a sweet man *g* (mine likes such fragrances), which also surprisingly lasts well on the skin and hardly changes in its presence.

Autumn can come! (well, actually it’s almost here already *laugh*)

review_title: Dark Chocolate Mousse with Toothpaste Topping
review_content:
Cara, is that really you?!?
I heard you’re supposed to be quite sweet and playful, you actually sounded quite pretty...
Now that we’ve met in person, I have to say;
I thought I was facing a dark bitter chocolate dessert with liqueur.
Unsweetened almonds, generally no sweetness, rather bitter.
Maybe a little glass of Baileys...
I smell vanilla at 0%
An unexpected start, but it gets even stranger.
A bright dentist smell follows, which sometimes lurks in gourmand-tinged fragrances, mild toothpaste/mint gum, every vague gourmand note completely gone.
The scent now appears almost airy, like the cool freshness in the mouth after brushing teeth.
Really quite strange...

It remains a bitter musty After Eight chocolate, I guess I have to imagine vanilla with it,
roasted almonds without sugar with some insignificant powdery note somewhere in the background, which might be responsible for this mustiness that resonates.
For me, there’s no further development on the skin, it smells rather one-dimensional and weak, with just a hint of sweetness at the very end with its last strength.
And I had feared beforehand that it might be too sweet foody for me...

So I’m confused.
The fragrance pyramid and associative descriptions of others cannot align with my scent perception, unfortunately not even close...

Cara is the gentlest vanilla I have tested so far. Right from the start, it envelops me with its softness. After about half an hour, I was startled: marzipan. I really don't like that at all. But just half an hour later, the gentle vanilla was back and the marzipan had disappeared. And that's how it stayed for 14-15 hours.

review_title: Quite linear, but a special DNA
review_content:
Cara is a special fragrance.
It conveys its own vibes and definitely leans towards a sweet gourmand-like direction.
Additionally, it is quite powdery and has a certain spiciness.

Cara doesn't have many fragrance notes, and you can tell.
The scent progression is quite linear, but that's not a problem at all, as the DNA is so special.

What does the fragrance do?
Personally, it gives me associations with certain desserts. I definitely think of rice pudding or semolina pudding. Of course, the rice pudding or semolina pudding is refined with a good portion of vanilla.

Not much more happens for me, but I find that good.
It simply has something.
However, it is also not cloyingly sweet; it even comes across with a slight "spiciness."
A kind of sweet spiciness.
Difficult to describe more precisely.

In conclusion, Cara is a special and unique sweet fragrance. It doesn't fully match my taste, but I appreciate it.

The performance is okay.
It lasts about 6-7 hours on me, but it becomes relatively close to the skin fairly quickly.
At least that's how it is on my skin.

Do give it a try if you want to smell something like vanilla semolina pudding or rice pudding as a perfume.

review_title: Scent in Disguise - the Heart of the Matter?
review_content: At first, it was beautiful and gentle and sweet. Then it turned bitter. Then again heavenly soft. Then bitter. What is this fragrance doing? And how can I stop it? I simply prefer the pretty poodle over Mephistopheles! Aaaargh, this is driving me insane!

Finding Cara just before this fragrance was discontinued means the world to me.

In the 90s, The Body Shop had some glass bottles with perfume oil for testing. They were placed on a round tray.
They were really intensely fragrant and long-lasting. A drop was enough to fill a room with the scent.

The Vanilla Perfume Oil was my scent, love at first sniff. The fragrance of my youth … It was a wonderful and pure vanilla pudding or marshmallow smell, the most beautiful of all vanilla scents, intensely room-filling and long-lasting. A scent like a loving embrace, a scent to feel good … A scent that comforts you.
I needed nothing else. Until I could no longer repurchase it …
It was reformulated and later completely discontinued.

It never completely let me go …
Years later, I set out on a quest. Determined to find something comparable. Something that could similarly comfort my soul and satisfy my longing for it.

I sniffed through so many vanilla fragrances and oils, made many blind purchases because others described this or that scent as similar. But everything was far from my scent memory.

Until the day this unassuming 30ml bottle named “Cara” moved in with me. I had ordered it directly from the manufacturer at a special price in the outlet.

The adhesive label was already peeling off, it seemed rather unpromising to me. Until I sprayed it and almost cried. This is it, the scent of my youth, I was speechless and I could even stock up on it before it too was discontinued.

I’m a little surprised by the notes in this fragrance. I expected all pear, but it’s really heavy on the caramel.
My husband walked by me and said I smelled like a tree. A perplexing statement for sure, I asked to explain. He told me I smelled like tree sap. Hmmm. He didn’t like it.
I do, however.

Pear Tree smells like a vanilla dessert. Cake, perhaps, but more like pie. Pie with vanilla ice cream.
It’s great for the holidays!

Sillage: 4 feet, so really good
Longevity: good
Bottle: average

review_title: My new friend Francesca - At Mazzolari in Milan
review_content:
At Easter, I went to Milan and a visit to Mazzolari was a must. I own Vaniglia, which I love very much, and wanted to get to know the other Mazzolari fragrances, as they unfortunately do not sell sample sets. Mazzolari has 4 stores in Milan, I was in a beautiful old building near the Duomo.
The lively and very communicative saleswoman Geraldina advised me very competently. I was looking for a fresher summer scent. She recommended Francesca, which she perceives as very cheerful. I agree.
Francesca starts off citrusy fresh, shortly after that aquatic notes blend in, which I perceive throughout the entire fragrance development. It becomes slightly powdery, a few flowers peek through, until a fluffy musk becomes more present. Generally, the scent reminds me of a sea breeze in Liguria, where, alongside the sea, many colorful flowers bloom and someone has hung fresh laundry in the narrow streets. I hardly notice patchouli and sandalwood.
I am looking forward to summer, when I will test Francesca in high temperatures. She will definitely accompany me on my trip to Liguria in July.

Kenzo Jungle is a fragrance I know from my childhood. My elementary school teacher used to wear it (hopefully still does today). It was very influential. Now I really wanted to try the men's version, as the original appealed to me and I didn't want to wear a women's perfume. I must say, there are definitely some parallels between the two. But the men's fragrance is much spicier. One could say it is an early precursor to Spicebomb EdT. Not quite as sweet, a bit woody, but a full spice bomb. Sniffing out individual notes is impossible for me. But the interplay is superb. For me, it's an exotic spicy scent for cold days.

Longevity and sillage are very good, similar to Spicebomb, easily 6 to 7 hours, and you will definitely be noticed. If you don't want that, you should avoid this fragrance. If you can still find it (I have the 100ml version), it's usually around 50 to 60 euros. That's a fair price. The bottle with the zebra brush is thematically fitting, creative, and I like it.

Normally, I’m not a fan of Kenzo. Neither Homme, Night, nor Power appeal to me, although I wouldn’t deny that all three fragrances have a distinct character. Accordingly, my expectations for Jungle were rather low, especially since I couldn’t really imagine the interplay of the mentioned ingredients. Well, the result can definitely be appreciated on my skin. However, I do have to deduct points for the zebra-like "bush" on the cap of the bottle. But for those who need a built-in brush for cleaning electric shavers or similar, this might be a delight! ;-)

Now to the scent: It exudes a fresh-warm aura, fitting for the climate zone it’s named after. I would describe it as unisex rather than distinctly masculine. Fortunately, the indicated sweetness is very subtle and does not rely on the often typical tonka-vanilla combination. Citrusy wood is probably what my nose perceives the most. But there’s something else that, like with most Kenzos, provides an extremely individual note. I can’t really attribute this to any specific ingredient and would describe it as balsamic, with a hint of floral and powdery nuances.

Thus, a rounded and harmonious overall scent emerges with long-lasting wear and a pleasant sillage, more soft than abrasive, yet still very special. For me, Jungle fits perfectly into the urban jungle and is universally wearable, meaning suitable for any season and occasion. However, those expecting something herbaceous-green or even resinous-leathery from the name are mistaken. Jungle is convincingly gentle harmony that has been overlooked for far too long!

Strong, spicy fragnance.
I can feel lots of Spice connected with oriental aura around. Mystery and strong fragnance into it, interesting combination.
Its unisex, but I personally think its more for women.
Sillage is above-average, longevity too.

review_title: Exceptional value but no wow factor for me
review_content:
Qaa'ed opens sweet spicy. Sweetness was a bit much for me, but as it dried down it became much less sweet. It then focused on the woody notes, mainly the sandalwood and oud with the carnation adding a nice bite. Mild vanilla was there; wouldn't call this a strong vanilla scent. Finally got subtle whiffs of leather. Very unique fragrance. Longevity is quite good while the sillage was only moderate for me. Considering the price, Qaa'ed is an exceptional value.

All that said, Qaa'ed didn't wow me. Will probably not be getting a FB.

review_title: Been 'macerating' since 2021, still horrible, send help
review_content:
I bought Qaa’ed for my husband in 2021 and all four of us have rued the day I did ever since. Taken in (and not for the last time, I bet) by all the mentions on Fragrantica of warm gingerbread or cardamom cookies, and conveniently ignoring all the reviews that mentioned how it smelled like a loud men’s aftershave, I imported it at some expense from Indian eBay, from whence it was dispatched – it seemed to me, given the seven weeks it took to arrive – on the back of manatees and elephants.

Exotic back story and all, you might say my expectations were high. One spray was enough to reveal the gravity of my mistake. Give it some time to ‘macerate’ they said, and that synthetic-smelling roar will die down to reveal the glories of a highly spiced, leathery, caramelized woody scent. Reader, it’s been three full years since this thing got shoved to the back of the sock drawer, and having pulled it out again just now, it is with a heavy heart that I inform you that Qaa’ed needs a full 36 months of aging to smell a mere 10% better than it did when you first opened the bottle.

Rather than tell you what’s ok about this scent (a short list indeed, and includes the bottle), I am going to tell you about what’s wrong with it. First of all, the combination of treacly, syrupy sweet notes over those brash ‘burnt wood’ aromachemicals make it smell like any generic designer scent that markets itself as ‘smoky’ or ‘oriental’ these days – anything that comes in a black bottle, basically – and is unfortunately close to the chemical marshmallow BBQ stench of By the Fireplace. The cardamom and other spice notes barely register against the burnt but radiant woody amber, so the gingerbread cookies remain trapped in your hopes and dreams rather than making it out there on your arm. Lastly, its spicy masculine leather notes take it beyond the outer limits of my personal gender stretchiness – I would no more wear this than I would Brut or Old Spice (but obviously, I am not you, so you do you).

Lastly – and yes, I know I already promised that the last point was ‘lastly’ but since my hatred of this knows no bounds, I shall continue – it contains a sulfurous chemical that smells like boiled cabbage or broccoli farts, which means it’s giving a little Hard Leather, another monstrosity, this time of the Norlimbanol sort.

review_title: Spice & Leather: A Winning Blind Buy
review_content: I took a chance on this fragrance after seeing mixed reviews, and I'm so glad I did! The initial spray is a burst of warm, spicy notes – cardamom and cinnamon dominate, creating a comforting and intense opening. As a fan of bold scents like Spicebomb Extreme, I was immediately hooked. The drydown reveals a smooth leather note alongside the lingering cardamom. Overall, it's a warm, masculine, and spicy fragrance that punches way above its price point. Solid performance too, with 7 hours of longevity and 2 hours of decent projection.

review_title: Great For Other Ppl, Not for Me
review_content:
I know this is a well-loved fragrance in scent review spaces, yet I’m struggling get at why. Albeit, leather is highly dominant here and I’m definitively not a leather fan. I’m also quite new to the Oud train and I’m still learning to appreciate that historical, divisive note. From others’ reactions, this must be a great scent but perhaps not a great scent for me.

To my nose, on this paper strip, I get an artificial Oud and amber at the base with spices and spicy florals (carnations or geranium maybe?) at the top. Even on a test strip, it’s super clear this scent is optimal during cold weather. My reaction may also be coming from the fact that it’s currently 96 F/35.5 C and this scent would truly choke someone out in the heat.

I like most of the notes otherwise. To give this an honest and true fair shake, I’ll try another test strip when the temperature dips.

review_title: Vegan Apricot and Peach Leather Tanned in Saffron Solution, Finished with Cardamom Polish
review_content: ◘Simplified fragrance pyramid: Top note: Peach blossom or magnolia, slightly piercing ethereal tones Heart note: Apricot pulp, peach skin, mango flesh, cardamom, rose geranium Base note: Saffron extract, vegan (synthetic) leather, balsamic wood, chemical fixatives ________________________________________________________________ ◘Range intensity (projection &...

Sometimes, when the scent perception deviates so extremely, it seems like you must have smelled a completely different perfume than the rest. That's how I feel about Qaa'ed. The good news: that's not a problem at all, because what I smell is so good that I will definitely be getting a full bottle. Even though it is neither what is listed in the pyramid nor what the majority of...

All of this crossed my mind when I first heard about Lattafa.
This fragrance is distinctly different from all the others in my collection.
Very masculine, oriental/spicy. Primarily smells of cardamom, cloves & cinnamon, while being completely unsweet.
For the first 30 minutes, an intense leather note prevails... To my surprise, the scent smells very natural and not synthetic at all.
I like to use it for layering with sweet-spicy/powdery fragrances like THE ONE EDP / DIOR HOMME INTENSE / Givenchy Gentleman or Givenchy PI.
Fortunately, it's affordable enough for a blind buy.
Worn solo, it's a bit too intense for me personally.
Longevity easily 12 hours.
Sillage on my skin is a maximum of 7.

And that refers to the price. After the first test, I couldn't believe at all that this fragrance is so inexpensive. I paid €18. And it comes across as significantly more expensive.
The scent starts off spicy sweet with a hint of saffron. The nutmeg is clearly noticeable and remains throughout the entire development, but is quickly enveloped by softer notes like vanilla and sandalwood. A fascinating interplay of the individual components, similar to what I experienced with Carlisle by PDM. Later, oud and leather join in, giving it a somewhat profound and mysteriously intriguing character. It's clear from the beginning that this is an oriental fragrance. But that it only costs a pittance, I still can't believe. Just the packaging is significantly better than many others. It comes in a round presentation box covered in faux leather. Longevity and sillage are also very good, by the way. I can only recommend that everyone give this fragrance a chance.

review_title: Oh wow, does this smell good..
review_content:
When I unpacked this perfume, I thought wow, very nice packaging and the bottle is very high quality!
Sprayed it on and, wow..
Great scent, sprayed again and I was thrilled.
I am a fan of oriental fragrances, this one is not too strong and overpowering, but still present.
It smells slightly sweet, then there’s something I can’t quite define yet.
(Sry, I just recently started my passion for perfumes..)
Then I also smell a hint of leather, very pleasant..
It lasts on my skin about 6-8 hours, which I find quite okay..
For me, it’s definitely an everyday scent, also suitable for the office!
In the evening, or among many people, I would prefer other scents..
But everyone has different preferences..
I can definitely recommend this perfume. And at the affordable price, you can’t really go wrong..
Otherwise, there’s always the souk here.. ;))

By the way, my first review here, maybe not the best, but hopefully helpful for one or the other.. I will train my nose better in the future.. ;))

That's what you get: checked Parfumo again and whoops, a new drug in the assortment... Many thanks to everyone - without you, I would never have come across this direction of fragrances from the East. I would have definitely missed out on something.
The first contact was quite piercing and scratchy; I also clearly noticed the motor oil mentioned in a comment. First thought: "Well, of course, at this price." But as often in life, good things take time. Once the top notes have evaporated, it becomes magnificent! Spicy, warm, clean, and quite oriental. In fact, it is similar to a spicier version of "Felce Azzurra" (Paglieri), as someone described it.
At first, I had doubts about whether I should really consider Qua'eed unisex. Although I do wear men's fragrances from time to time. (Calvin Klein, Zino, Lagerfeld, Joop...) In the meantime, I've made up my mind: it fits!! Moreover, I find it incredibly appealing that this liquid dream doesn't come off as mainstream but has its own edges. Anyone can be pleasant; one must allow oneself to be extravagant...!!
At the moment, I can't go without it. But be careful: when it comes to dosage, one should probably exercise restraint. And I say this mainly to myself, because I love to really go for it. When I go to work, I hold back... But now it's the weekend, and I'm going to let loose!! I am a talking room fragrance in my house and feel absolutely wonderful in this spicy cloud!

Diving into the spice world of Arabia? Without traveling there? Here’s a good solution: Spray on "Quaa'ed" and get started. Float on the "flying carpet," surf through the air, like a wave rider gliding through the water on his surfboard. Just slower. A first good impression of the spice world is offered by a nutmeg dusted with saffron threads. Shimmering in brown and...

review_title: The best second fiddle in the world
review_content: About 3 months ago, this perfume arrived at my place and left an impressive first impression. The subtle packaging made of synthetic leather is lined inside with a slightly rough satin. Inside, there is the golden bottle... made of plastic, but still appealing. I took it out and sprayed it five times on a piece of paper: Phew, brutal, gasoline-like, and piercing. A clear...

Another Lattafa that should not go unreviewed by me. This one has already earned quite a bit of attention, especially because, like most Lattafa fragrances, it is sold well below its value. This is already an original creation by Lattafa, without much resemblance to a more well-known bestseller. It is indicated as a flanker of Issey Miyake, but I doubt that this was...

Okay...where do I start. The bottle and the entire presentation upon arrival are very elegant. As seen in the picture, the fragrance comes in a beautiful packaging. This is covered in artificial leather and unfortunately smells unpleasantly chemical. The bottle has a nice gold metal look, which turned out to be plastic. Still quite nice to look at. Now to the fragrance. It...

At first, the scent was somewhat peculiar and took some getting used to. It felt a bit distant from the beast. I bought it in the summer, so I thought I’d let it mature until autumn. And that definitely did the perfume good! Now it lasts incredibly long and is very noticeable. The scent has also become "rounder" and very elegantly spicy and woody. I’m now in love. In...

The packaging already gives a hint of what to expect. You essentially open a "leather" box and behold a golden bottle with beautiful lettering.
Upon spraying, you immediately smell the notes of musk, saffron, and oud that are characteristic of Lattafa. A very, very nice leather note joins in.
The longevity and sillage of this fragrance are very good for Lattafa's standards! I mean that Lattafa generally has good to very good longevity, but this fragrance leans more towards the strong to very strong side in terms of longevity and sillage.

What I've noticed here.
I have to say that some spices tend to repeat themselves in Lattafa fragrances, and you can "recognize" them again. This is not really a problem unless you are absolutely not a fan of them.
For example, take "Ameer Al Oudh Intense Oud | Lattafa / لطافة" and "Oud Mood (Eau de Parfum) | Lattafa / لطافة" and this one "Qaa'ed | Lattafa / لطافة"
ALL 3 have saffron in the top note and also a bit in the further development of the fragrance. You can smell this clearly, and it is the same in all 3! If you don't like it, it's best to skip all 3 fragrances (:

I also distinctly smell other well-known fragrance notes that I won't go into further. What I want to convey is that I feel or can smell that Lattafa takes a kind of "base" of fragrance notes here and always mixes in a new twist.
Here with "Qaa'ed | Lattafa / لطافة" it is the leather, with "Oud Mood (Eau de Parfum) | Lattafa / لطافة" it is the rose, and with "Ameer Al Oudh Intense Oud | Lattafa / لطافة" it is the resinous, woody note.

Overall, the fragrances are all good, and the longevity and sillage are sometimes fantastic! But they don't differ too much. Those expecting a completely different scent might be disappointed.

A spiciness that, as an inexperienced perfume beginner, slightly overwhelmed me with the very first spray. However, the second sniff reveals the clearly present sweetness, which provides a very pleasant contrast and makes the scent incredibly delicious in combination. The longer the fragrance stays on the skin, the sweeter it becomes, accompanied by a light woody note. This woody-sweet base and the strong cardamom note make it one of my current go-tos.
Due to the prominent cardamom, it even vaguely reminds me of the widely popular "La Nuit de L'Homme," but it feels somewhat more complex and lasts significantly longer.
For an oriental fragrance, it is overall very pleasing yet somewhat special.
The indicated oud in the heart note is perceived rather briefly and fortunately not at all animalistic or overwhelming.
I see Qaa'Ed more as a scent for the evening, in a stylish setting and well-dressed.
It is also suitable for everyday wear, but I do avoid it in the office. I find (and so do my colleagues) the sillage to be quite strong, though not completely overpowering. With such strong scents, I tend to refrain from bombarding my colleagues in the office.

Absolutely no one would guess that this fragrance is available for under €20. It smells really high-quality, surprisingly natural, and exciting. I have not encountered a better price-to-quality ratio with any perfume so far.

I personally find the bottle beautiful and eye-catching, although my wife commented, "It looks like it’s from a flea market." I can't relate to that. Of course, the golden casing is made of plastic, but the bottle still has a certain appeal.

Qaa'ed.. what can I say. You smell so much more expensive, high-quality, exquisite (...) than you actually are.

Although the fragrance is listed for men, I think women can rock it just as well. Sure, the opening smells quite masculine, but after a minute, the aftershave opening has already faded away.

What unfolds is a carpet of smoky woods, leather, sweet spices, and vanilla. And it stays that way until it slowly fades away.

The longevity is truly enormous.. and the sillage leaves nothing to be desired. On clothing, it can still be smelled for days..

Worn alone, it is a masterpiece, but together with the fragrance oil Choco Musc, Schmitz's cat really takes off. A combo made for each other - definitely give it a try!

As the title suggests, the elegance begins with the packaging and the bottle.
The presentation truly has no equal in this price category.
The fragrance itself is not abrasive; rather, it is a wonderful companion in autumn and winter.
Lovely spices in the top note meet gentle wood in the heart, gradually receiving slightly sweet vibrations from the vanilla.

review_title: A great scent for a tight budget
review_content: Many thanks to Sören for the sample :-) With "Qaa'ed | Lattafa / لطافة," you are dealing with a fragrance that appears surprisingly luxurious for the price. Fortunately, there are no similarities to the "artificial leather sofa scent" "Qaa'ed al Shabaab | Lattafa / لطافة," which I found quite unpleasant. The longevity is quite good at 7-9 hours, and the sillage is...

review_title: A Budget King That Deserves More Hype
review_content:
For months, I had been searching for a spicy-oriental fragrance that isn't too overpowering or screams bazaar.

During a sniffing excursion at "Haltane | Parfums de Marly," which was definitely out of my budget at the time, I stumbled upon Qaa'ed through Parfumo. By the way, the two fragrances have very little in common (why they are listed as "similar" remains a mystery to me).

Fortunately, I like Qaa'ed, for which I promptly got a decant, much better - at least for the actual purpose of explicitly searching for something spicy-oriental:
A woody heart surrounded by nutmeg and saffron. In the drydown, a light but noticeable hint of vanilla comes through. The initially quite dominant nutmeg becomes pleasantly tamed and is complemented by a leathery note.

With a longevity of 7-8 hours and a moderate sillage (which diminishes a bit after 5 hours), Qaa'ed is already a price-wise no-brainer, but it doesn't stop there:

The presentation leaves (in typical Lattafa fashion) little to be desired. Just from its appearance, one could easily find oneself in the 10-20 times price range.
The faux leather feels more premium than most counterparts used in accessories or automobiles. Positive madness!

Why Qaa'ed doesn't receive the hype of "Khamrah / خمرة | Lattafa / لطافة" or "Asad | Lattafa / لطافة" is beyond me. Clones or not. As one of the cheapest fragrances from Lattafa, Qaa'ed is one of the few Lattafa scents that made me think, "my goodness, this smells like really good niche!"

On this creamy sandalwood-vanilla-oud base lies an interesting spice, particularly consisting of nutmeg, which I perceive strongly at least in the first half hour.

The (nutmeg) top note then gradually fades away, taking with it some of the magic, the uniqueness, the intrigue, but leaving behind a warm creamy veil with little leather, which has lost its entire sillage after 2-3 hours.

For just around 17 euros, it's a good addition to any collection for those who want a warm vanilla-sandalwood scent with that certain extra.
But also thanks to its good longevity and sillage, it's worth a blind buy.

Definitely more of an autumn and winter fragrance for me, or generally for cool evenings, where the vanilla and sandalwood bring a certain warmth and the nutmeg adds a bit of pep to the atmosphere.

If someone had asked me before the last Star Wars films who the hero of my childhood was, I would have probably answered without hesitation, “Han Solo.” And if someone had then asked me what Han Solo smells like, I would have probably replied after some thought: “Like my Uncle Walter.” Because in reality, Uncle Walter was the hero of my childhood. Black mullet hair,...

At the start, it's smoky and woody, and over time a gentle, subtly sweet, vanilla note joins in. Overall, it creates an incredibly smooth impression; a scent can't be rounder for me. This is how I imagine a "warming" companion for cold times, one you want to snuggle up to. It leans somewhat towards "Halston Man Amber | Halston," but is softer and feels even more balanced to me. A fragrance that won't clash anywhere.

By the way, I can't understand the similarity to "Midnight Oud (Eau de Parfum) | Ard Al Zaafaran / ارض الزعفران التجارية" at all; for me, there are no parallels whatsoever.

The bottle is great, and the sprayer, like with most Lattafas, is good. However, I particularly want to highlight the packaging here. I have really thrown away every packaging so far, except for the can of "Le Mâle Eau Fraîche Popeye Edition | Jean Paul Gaultier." But I will keep the one from Qaa'ed. Either Lattafa manages to give faux leather a perfectly authentic leather scent, or Qaa'ed actually comes in a can that is covered with real, very fine leather. I don't actually think it's great when an animal product is used unnecessarily, but I find it worth mentioning because I haven't seen anything like this before.

review_title: A Gentle Rose, Wrapped in Silk.
review_content:
This is the only Tauer I have tried, that has come across as soft. I was expecting a deep, dark,and rich fragrance, and I was really surprised at how this came across, well, for me anyhow).
The opening is really interesting..I didn't detect any rose first off, it is more of a wisp of gentle smoke,with a touch of the almond and apricot. I have found this slight smoke accord to be present in most of the Tauer perfumes, but this is only a faint touch in this fragrance. I must say, the rose accords are very light, and soft. In his other creation. Une Rose Chypree) my favorite of his rose fragrances, The Rose is very pronounced, and bold. It's almost as if this rose is hiding in the mist, and just peeking through. This fragrance, in my opinion, is very feminine..even though it's classed as a unisex fragrance).The dry down is very soft, as well, and I did re-apply after two hours to have a sort of second round of options. I enjoyed wearing it, but was expecting something much stronger, or perhaps bolder is a better word. Another interesting point, every review I have read on this fragrance has been really varied. Some have said it's really rich, and bold, others have had a similar experience to mine, in that it is a soft scent. It doesn't come across as very sweet, I would say the notes are very nicely balanced. The slight tobacco note is pleasant, and there seems to be just a touch of patchouli..which stays very close to the skin. I didn't find the sillage strong, but it is detectable. I hope to order this in the Tauer Explorer set, as I do like it, Yes, a lovely, but gentle Rose, wrapped in the softest silk.

Opening is a handful.
It starts out unapologetic.
All notes radiating at maximum capacity.
Bitter almond (no sweetness) and apricot made dusty by the tobacco leaves. A faint sparkle from the bergamot.
The tonka balances the patchouli.
No dainty frills.
There's an overall austere mood to it.
There's a strong correlation between it & Rahat Loukoum.
I'm getting a likeness to that supple leather & plum accord in Boxeueses.
But here it's supple leather & almond.
I'm GLAD the rose isn't prominent at all.
We all love roses but there are enough outstanding rose perfumes available.
There is rose and I can tell its not the regular fluffy rose but its not rose centered.

Then an interplay of notes commences.
Here is where Andy's craftsmanship in complexity is most vivid.

The premise is as such:
A bonding of gourmand & noir (leathery resinous accord)
Composition :
The apricot & almond create a marzipan accord. The gourmand aspect.
The tobacco (excessive use of) , geranium & musk make up the noir effect.
This demonstrates Andy's craftsmanship with complex compositions.
It opens with strong presence then harmoniously transitions to its peak purpose -interplay of gourmand & leathery/resinous (dark)- and then settles to a base that is the sum of all its parts.
I'd have named it Marzipan Noir.

Andy Tauer's latest rose creation is another gem. A gem as such. I don't know what PHI stands for, but I read in his blog that it is a rose scent with precious, natural absolue ingredients ... and therefore a limited edition. The next harvest oil may not turn out the same exact batch. Notes and technical background are not my forte, but what I can put is my impression of this perfume.

It envelops you like a soft cloud. Roses, roses with a touch of slighty bitter brownness ... I suppose the cinnamon, geranium and almond have something to do with that. That takes the edge of a brilliant rose and makes an almost skin scent, so warm and close. It projects only a little, actually I had to spray on a lot, but then it lasts the major part of the day. The beauty is that the sillage and skin smell alike, and I cannot stop stiffing up closely and delight how good it smells.

It does not hit the nose like mainstream perfumes do with a boost of flowerbomb notes and a lot of sweetness, rather it is a soft veil where beautiful, delectable, almost gourmand (caramel candy) notes swirl around also. Tobacco leaves? Maybe. If so, that is one good aromatic soft and subtle tobacco.

The best reviews you will find in Kafka's blog. Refer to that if you really want to know.

If I did not have already similar perfumes, I would buy it when it is available in a Tauer Perfumes Explorer Set. Those are easier for shipping as postal air shipment restrictions hinder the flow.

Thumbs up. Another scent well worthy of Andy Tauer's reputation. I have the feeling that it may become a landmark, a big success.

PHI opens with a slightly fruity apricot, with whiffs of piercing rose and bitter almond. As the composition moves to its early heart the rose remains in support, but moderately powdery, slightly creamy vanilla emerges as co-star with the slightly bitter almond. During the late dry-down the composition is all about the powdery vanilla that turns relatively dry, supported by rooty vetiver, light musk and remnants of the almond losing its bitter facet through the finish. Projection is excellent, as is longevity at nearly 15 hours on skin.

Let's get the positive aspects of PHI out of the way quickly... The composition has some great performance metrics and is obviously well-made. In addition to the impressive performance, the composition has a tolerable late dry-down that is unobtrusive and wearable. OK, now that is out of the way we can focus on the rest of the composition's attributes, and they all disappoint big time. Maybe disappoint is unfair because that implies one expected something better to begin with. I feel guilty panning yet another one of Mr. Tauer's compositions, but something about his trademark dusty vanilla base is just so annoying it ruins every one of them, and PHI is no exception. Also not helping matters is that while rose is supposedly the featured note (and it certainly is in the composition) the bitter almond mixed with the dusty, slightly sweet vanilla really is the focus and it doesn't smell good. I wouldn't go as far as to say the composition is a scrubber, but I did think about it several times, particularly in the key mid-section as the vanilla almond is at its strongest and most displeasing. At the end of the day the only one to blame for my torture in wearing this is me. I haven't found one Tauer composition I have liked yet, so why would I expect any different with PHI? The bottom line is the $160 per 50ml PHI Une Rose de Kandahar has a couple positive attributes easily drowned by an avalanche of negatives, earning it a "poor" rating of 2 stars out of 5 and an avoid recommendation.

This is a phenomenal fragrance! Really beautiful stuff. So far I have never been disappointed by any fragrance by Andy Tauer. This is my third one. I have to say I am enjoying this one quite a lot.

To me this is typical of most Tauer fragrances. It is a heavy, spicy kind of smell. My first love was his fragrance Le Maroc pour Elle which was inspired by Morocco, and which had heavy amber, jasmine and spices. This one has it's origins in Afghanistan. Kandahar is a very famous city there and close by there are fields near the mountains where poppies are grown (for opium). Afghanistan is not all desert, there are many high mountains with snow and green fields and fruit trees all fed by ice cold mountain water from the rivers and streams. In such a place, roses also grow, a "mountain rose"... and those are the roses used by Tauer in this fragrance.

It opens up with heavy spice, with almonds, tobacco, cinnamon, bergamot. For me the strongest note here is the tobacco. Dry tobacco leaves mixed with spices (the same leaves used to make cigars). I think there is a rose here, but it's not quite a "rose" fragrance. It;s a deep, spicy perfume with a little rose. A very "dusty" rose. I also get the ambergris, tonka bean, vetiver, patchouli and vanilla. It's very dark. If this fragrance had a colour, I think it would be dark red, or like a brown red colour. This is like deep, dark red wine. It has the same feeling to me. Personally I like it, but I know it may be a little heavy and "weird" for some people out there.

Une Rose de Kandahar is a fragrance with quite a unique smell (but not unique if you know the Tauer house). It's a very spicy scent with heavy musk as well as rose. So don't expect a huge rose in your face. But I think it's really beautiful. I sprayed it on earlier and one or two sprays stayed with me for at least 3 hours. It's a very beautiful fragrance. I would say only buy this if you are a huge fan of the Tauer house. Because it is a limited edition (he buys the rose oil from only one field in Afghanistan and each year the roses finish... so he has to wait until the next year to make more perfume). That's why it is a limited edition. One to try and sample first (because of the high price).

I don't know if it is my chemistry but this perfume on my skin falls flat. The sweetness is a little sickly and I didn't get the brightness I expected from the fruits. The tobacco is there somewhere underneath the sugar but quite faint. The rose is ok but it is not a blooming rose. In a similar genre but to me a more successful execution is Isparta from Pierre Guillaume. It is...

review_title: A rose is a rose is a rose
review_content: I used to love all rose-based fragrances and then I lost the fling. Most of them started boring me or even irritate. And then comes PHI: so not obvious, delicate and perfectly mixing with its company- geranium and my fav patchouli. I have a pleasure to just sit and feel how it changes with time. I did some layering with Olibanum and after an hour I have a...

review_title: Why rose and white musk smells like baby powder to Americans, and not to Europeans - an explanation
review_content: The scent opens with booziness for me, which is very nice. After the opening, it settles into a dusty, earthy rose. There is a slight cooling sensation on the nose. There is something very baby powder about this once we get into the drydown, and I cannot trick my brain into thinking of marzipan. Reading online, the scent of the classic North American Johnson & Johnson baby...

Not sure who said this, but this quote came into my mind when I smelled this perfume and it could be an alternative name for it. Why? Because its a dusty earthy floral scent...not an ordinary rose scent.

Generally:

I am not fan of rose fragrances even the most known as oud satin mood, atomic rose, etc. Its just not my taste... I believe that because I am used to smelling rose in other things at home, like cloth detergent, closet scent sachets, room diffusers and other things we use at home, that I am bored of this scent and I just dont want it on me. Or at least I dont want it when it has the main role in the fragrance. All those home stuff are most targeted for women so most of them has a rose scent.
Lately, I was obsessed into getting a rose fragrance so I started testing the most known and high rated rose fragrances such as portrait of a lady, rose d arabie, rose de mai, a la rose, intense cafe, wardasina, radical rose, etc , but none of them made me reach my wallet for it! Desperately, I decided to blind buy one. Une rose de Kandahar. I have read all good stuff about this fragrance even that its a gourmand (I love gourmands) so I decided to make the move.

About the fragrance:

When I first sprayed it, I wasnt blown away like "OMG. this is awesome", I was just "hm...ok...not bad...". This scent is the type of scent that gives you headaches with its intensity that I believe its coming from the bergamont, the bourbon geranium and the patchouli. From its notes, I dont get any cinnamon, vanilla, vetiver and tonka. It is a very dusty, dirty, powdery rose enhanced by geranium and patchouli in a beautiful well blended way. It is a sweet scent but I would not characterize it as Gourmand. Its not that sweet because of the intese dustiness.

Most common questions:

How will you characterize the scent?
It is a powdery dirty sweet rose scent.

Is it a safe blind buy or a gift?
No to both. Its a diffiucult scent, not an ordinary mass appealing scent. You need time to understand and appreciate it.

Is it for women or men?
This scent is totally unisex and I must say that I will love it more on a man.

Is it for summer or winter?
Definitely a scent for cold weather.

What occasions can I wear it?
It is not an everyday scent that you can wear at the office or to chill out with friends. Its a scent that you can wear in formal occasions with a dress or a tux.

Does it reminds you of another rose fragrance?
No. Une rose de Kandahar, is far from an ordinary rose scent and this is what I loved in it and kept it. It has the Tauer DNA, its like Au Cuer du Desert or L air du Desert but with rose...

Thank you for your time, hope I helped you understant it.

Stay safe and smell great!

the progression of scents for me went like this:
1 - very strong acrid rose, the metallic acridity went away quickly however then came a very fresh, green rose.
2 - rose strongly infused with peach.
3 - a very lovely powdery rose finish. very beautiful at the end.
for me this scent did not have very good sillage or longevity - it was mostly gone in 3 hours.

Pros: this perfume is strong. A single spritz will last you all day, so therefore I imagine one bottle could last quite awhile. Cons: I get that this is all just personal taste, but I'm not a fan of this scent at all. It's very heavy feeling/smelling to me. Also, unfortunately, it smells very much like a perfume my great grandmother wore (the rose notes are very similar) so...

review_title: He who seeks reality finds poetry
review_content:
Originality doesn’t come from a desire to be unique, but from a desire to be sincere.
This is true for perfume, as it is for everything else.
And sincerity begins when we ask questions, when we explore.

Jón Kalman Stefánsson once wrote:
"He who seeks reality finds poetry.
He who seeks poetry finds himself.
He who seeks himself can travel between worlds."

I don’t know if Andy Tauer can travel between worlds,
but I’m quite certain he’s searching for poetry—his own kind of poetry.

And the rose he brought back from his universe smells like no other.
It’s a rose of almond paste, vanilla, and apricot.
Beautiful enough to be kept under a glass dome,
but far too innocent to be robbed of its freedom.

Phi (that’s her name) isn’t a seducer’s rose.
It’s an honest one—perhaps even a gourmand—
one that makes mistakes, but means every word.

And we always underestimate just how seductive sincerity can be.

Insta: switzer_scent

review_title: Divine natural modern kind of rose scent. It’s a LOVE!
review_content: I’m very picky on rose fragrances as they are normally very feminine or mature but this one is very different, rich but not strong, unisex, and modern. Love this rose mix with almond, tobacco and vanilla. Plus the slight touch of the apricot. The whole composition makes it a smooth warm gourmandy scent. The rose smells so high quality. It becomes one of favorite rose fragrances besides Oud Satin Mood and Intense Cafe. These are the only 3 roses I like so far. The only downside is that the performance is considerably weak compared to other Andy Tauer creations although it’s still better than many fragrances out there. Lasts only 7-8 hours and projects only for 3 hours on my skin, then would turn to skin scent but the scent is so gorgeous enough to make me overlook the performance issue. Love Love Love!

This one surprised me with its creative take on a rose gourmand. And not the usual rose and chocolate combo, but rather, an apricot, almond, and vanilla rose. It’s sweet and alluring with bright stone fruit and gentle cinnamon at the opening, and dries down to include an addictive nutty tobacco tonka combo that has me sniffing my wrist all day. This is my favorite rose to date, and a scent I can’t stop thinking about. Highly considering a bottle...

One of the more accessible scents from this house, and yet still quite unique and interesting. Lovely rose is accompanied by green notes, tobacco, and tonka bean, all of which are kept in careful balance. A bit of sweetness keeps this quite approachable, while the spiciness adds some mystery. The base is warm and delicious, without being overly gourmand.

I like it.

Insanely great perfume i do own full bottle only for special ocassions but if u have the money u can use it everyday, its close to like exlusives or private collection from designer brands, extremely high quality hand made in Switzerland, smells unique rose de kandahar is truly unique rose fragrance + bg roses sweet long lasting and moderately projection stuff. + tons of compliments.

review_title: An attempt to say it with flowers! Clichés, phrases, expressions!
review_content:
Let’s get up close and personal with the perfume and see if the chemistry is right.
Let’s take a closer look at Rose de Kandahar, separating the wheat from the chaff.

The scent comes on strong like Blücher, there’s no skimping, only boldness.
At first, the apricot-like fruitiness hits immediately with a fresh-spicy punch.
Cinnamon throws its hat into the ring but quickly shifts down a gear.
Bitter almond stands at the ready, ensuring that sweetness doesn’t take center stage.
The rose is still a shadow of its former self, backed against the wall.
The strong scent of damp hay conceals the rose like a needle in a haystack.

It’s high time for the rose, or it won’t be worth a shot of powder.
And it won’t let anyone take the butter off its bread, stepping up its game.
The rose rises like a phoenix from the ashes and makes a powerful statement.
It masters its rosy facets effortlessly, everything is in harmony.
We’re floating on cloud nine, experiencing a scent sensation as if resting on roses.
The slight bitterness of the almond remains the salt in the not-so-sweet soup.
To counter the floral nature of the rose, tobacco is raised as a banner.

The tobacco plays well against the rose and appears cheeky as Oscar.
The scent stands at a crossroads, but the rose keeps the tobacco in check.
The crux is that both have a lot going on behind the scenes.
Ultimately, the tobacco supports the rose and extends a hand.
The rosy-warm spiciness of both runs like a red thread through the scent.
But it’s not all over yet; not everything is settled.

The perfume base, as the ace up the sleeve, crowns the scent.
Cinnamon has made its exit, musty-woody vetiver plays the filler.
Vanilla gently knocks on the door but keeps the ball quite flat.
Bitter almond lingers almost to the bitter end but now gives up the spoon.
Marzipan-like tonka bean jumps into the breach, sweetness chuckles to itself.
Patchouli has a dirty secret, earthy-woody hits the nail on the head.
There we have the salad, but patchouli has made its calculations without the host.
This doesn’t take the wind out of the rose’s sails; it shows what it’s made of.
This rose is thorny and has teeth, earthy-floral it stays in the game.
And it maintains a bitter-sweet-dark grip until the end, lucky us.

As a rose scent, it’s the egg of Columbus; Une Rose de Kandahar hits the mark perfectly.
Thick air at arm’s length for about 6 hours, the end of the line is after 10 hours.
Packaging and Tauer bottle are old news; the high price doesn’t bother me.

A weight has been lifted from my heart. I hope you don’t get cold feet while reading,
don’t let your head hang low or grow gray hairs!
I’m keeping my fingers crossed for everyone!

review_title: Highly complex, multifaceted rose-tobacco-stone fruit oriental
review_content:
It has a lot to offer, this Tauer!

That we only know the city of Kandahar (unfortunately) from the news due to political turmoil and military conflicts is bad enough; the horrific events in Afghanistan have overshadowed any awareness of the culturally magnificent components of this world region and its neighboring countries for decades.

I don't just mean the valuable essences, spices, and resins that bring us Europeans so much joy in fragrances, but also the mythical Arabic music, beautifully played by Anouar Brahem, for example.

This connection is always fundamental for me, as a freshly applied oriental fragrance pairs wonderfully with said Arabic music in the background, allowing one to be atmospherically transported to the distant Orient.

The "Rose from Kandahar" truly deserves a longer, more elaborate commentary, as it represents a remarkable work of art.

The beginning already hints that much more aromatic richness will follow. First, it hits you hard, getting the entire olfactory apparatus into gear: lightly dried apricot slices, somewhat fruity and sweet, are paired with a very moderately used cinnamon. Here we already have the culinary Orient, which - and this is what makes Tauer's refinement - finds an ideal counterbalance in a beautifully contrasting bitter almond, preventing it from becoming too sweet or cloying.

In fact, this fragrance apparently always has two sides or two faces: superficially flattering, sweet, festive, yet subtly serious, dark, and contemplative.

The rose, which reveals itself in the apricot-cinnamon opening, is intense, powerful, and at times disturbing.
This is not an inviting or brightly feminine rose at first glance, but rather a shady, earthy, vegetal one.

This impression can be further intensified by a generously added tobacco absolute, which brings an incredible amount of grounding in the autumnal brown spectrum.

That the fragrance, despite this aromatic power, appears harmonious, aesthetic, and simply artistic may be attributed to the gentler base, which, in the form of tonka bean and mild patchouli, always allows the star, the complex rose, to take the lead, merely softening, dampening, and caressing around it.

Truly a highly remarkable and experiential fragrance, where one can indeed concede that the demanded premium price is not merely a show and image effect, but is based on excellent quality and artisanal mastery.

review_title: At least a promising side effect
review_content: I’ll keep it short: I can’t get along with ‘Une Rose de Kandahar’. I haven’t skimped on tests, always hoping for a learning effect. In vain, I consistently smell a layering, juxtaposition, jumble of aromas that simply refuse to come together for me. Bitter almond baking aroma (somehow mutating into tonka) on a layer of Tauer cream. Diffuse fruit along with vague...

"RhNUDX1 from Quandhar"

Many think that roses bloom only once a year. This is not true. The queen has her secrets, many secrets.

If you connect the tips of the petals of a wild rose two at a time, you get the Drudenfuß, the mystical pentagram, an ancient magical sign, the secret symbol that guarded the understanding of the harmonious structure of humanity and the universe. Therefore, the wild rose, which carefully seals its bud sanctuary from the outside world, became the embodiment of the mysterious and the discreet. Ultimately, this symbolism was transferred to all roses.

The fact that the rose has been regarded as a symbol of discretion since ancient times is said to stem from the following event: To hide the love affair of his mother, the goddess of love Venus, Cupid sent roses to Harpocrates, the god of silence, and asked him to keep the secret. The ancient Egyptians dedicated the rose to the god Harpocrates. The Romans hung a rose from the ceiling at gatherings to remind those present of their duty to silence. Pope Hadrian had confessionals adorned with rose carvings - on old confessionals, you can still occasionally see them - the decoration also known as the silent rose. The stucco rose above the common table had this meaning as well. In the High Middle Ages, rose images were also placed in wine taverns and council halls to allow for confidential conversations. Sometimes, a fresh rose would symbolically hang on the door of the city council to indicate "sub rosa." In England, it is a custom to place a sword on a table strewn with roses when the council meets to elect the Mayor of London. The Rosicrucians, a secret society, even carry the rose as a symbol of discretion in their name. The modern writer Umberto Eco also plays with this symbolism in his novel "The Name of the Rose"!

The rose is a mysterious and beautiful queen.

To describe the scent of the rose, everyday language simply lacks the words. In the high cultures of early history, the knowledge of plant scents and their application was alive and widespread. The realization that scents directly affect the human brain and can be used for healing is successfully applied today in aromatherapy.

The rose scent contains 450 known and 120 yet unknown components. The distribution on the flower is very different: in the outer part of the flower, rose alcohols - including citronellol, geraniol, and nerol - attract bees, bumblebees, and hornets. However, these substances repel other insects. Next, the pollinating insects enter a phenyl-ethanol intoxication. They crawl dizzily further into the center of the rose, where familiar scents like eugenol and citral greet them. The rather spicy, clove-like eugenol and citral, a warm citrus scent, are related to scents found in beehives. They wave their bodies and brush off the pollen of other flowers, leading to pollination. The scent of the rose solely aims to attract insects for pollination. Although bees cannot perceive the color red, they are still drawn to red roses because they are attracted by the scent and not by the color.

And humans?

Humans operate according to the pleasure principle. They seek fun and enjoyment. Scents are the only things that reach the brain directly without intermediaries. Therefore, scents offer us an incredible potential for pleasure.

“Une Rose de Kandahar” is lustful. Very lustful.

As the sixth fragrance ever, “Une Rose de Kandahar” makes it into my top 10 list. It is not easy to get in there. I am on a quest. I want to assign all categories to this one fragrance, such as the best leather scent, the best vetiver, etc.

“Une Rose de Kandahar” is for me THE rose scent. A fragrance like life itself, affirming, uplifting, fulfilling, and blissful. I do not like these comparisons with dead roses. This rose is alive. It breathes and laughs, enjoys life, and is like a small, blissful child. It rejoices and jumps in circles. Even if it comes from a painful place, this rose enchants me with its zest for life!
Quandhar was the place of the ancient Indo-Persian gathering, a trade hub and cultural meeting point between India, Central Asia, and the Middle East. Quandhar has been destroyed many times, yet we know that some things are virtually indestructible.

Just like the rose from Kandahar.

I believe that each of us hopes to leave some kind of mark, something "to be remembered for." Andy Tauer has created a masterpiece with this fragrance. No one can take that away from him. The rest of his fragrances somehow do not reach me, but this rose...

I have already written in my statement that I lack the words to describe this fragrance. Even today, I do not feel much better. My favorite author here, FabianO, has already said everything and more...fruity, rosy, shady, earthy, but all together a perfection. The perfection!

This fragrance is a must-have!

In this composition, in my opinion, what one calls the essence of a rose is preserved, namely the RhNUDX1. What is that?

https://www.google.com/search?client=firefox-b-d&q=RhNUDX1

When it hisses and crackles and strikes like lightning.
When your body trembles.
When the prickliest goosebumps spread across your body.
When it penetrates your skin like an invisible force that holds you captive.
When suddenly all stimuli and senses overwhelm you.
When your most intimate thoughts ride a wild carousel.
When your happiness hormones burst out of your body like Smarties.
When your ears buzz, muted by a breathtaking power.
When your knees tremble.
When you have sweaty hands.
When your heart almost skips into your pants.
When your eyes are covered by a fine, wet layer and you have to pause to avoid bursting into tears. Before a meter-thick layer of joy, as hard as a chunk of brick.
When all thoughts tear away from you and worries are thrown around the corner.
When silence spreads that you can hardly explain.
When everything points at you and attention turns against you..

Yes then - then you have been hit by the atomic bomb of Une Rose de Kandahar!

What a bombastic fragrance, in the truest sense of the word!
Une Rose de Kandahar is not a shy child of the perfume world, but a cunning bomb that penetrates your skin so vehemently that it is hard to pull it out from under it.
Nothing here suggests soft features, but rather many pronounced edges and extremely sharp corners.
And when a perfume makes my most intimate thoughts ride a wild carousel and takes me out of action, then everything has already been said and done. Done perhaps not yet, because it now ranks at the top of my wish list.

The atomic bomb begins its overture, as expected, with an unimaginable intensity. The scent rolls in with a towering, black wave that carries tons of cinnamon. In addition, a candied fruit already enters the scene. Spices are presented abundantly and have no intention of settling down quietly. Only slowly does the wave return to calm, and it is almost silent at sea. But then an unimaginably beautiful rose appears, making my spirit bloom. Yes, I praise the scent to the heavens, because this rose is truly something special. At first, it pricks me, then I only feel caresses. Rose petals on bare, pure skin. Dim light. Warm air. Sensory immersion. Completion. Ecstasy.

The longer I remain in this ecstasy, the less I am aware that strong tobacco leaves are seeping into the fragrance. It comes only gradually and not as harshly anticipated. Because I thought at first contact that the rose would play the concert all by itself. Far from it! The pairing of tobacco with the rose is a truly grand olfactory experience that I have rarely encountered. Tobacco, initially really rough and dense, then rather soft and flowing. Pure enjoyment!
