Cinnamon remains discreet in the background, giving the fragrance, along with the approaching vanilla, a gourmand touch. Tonka then crowns the whole thing. My heart feels warm.

Rose petals continue to fall upon me. Tobacco, over time, only adorns the background, and the rose makes it clear who has the say between them. As the scent winds down, it becomes only softly resinous, with a hint of smoke. This does not diminish the rose, as it takes another run-up. The gourmand touch always lingers in the scent. Like a slumbering phase of the Orient. Pink powder clouds adorn my dream. I would love to fall onto them inside and let myself be caught.

Quiet really means something else! A fragrance with enormous longevity and the sillage is truly noteworthy. It comes in! It annihilates many sensations, even if it also scares some. Because it is complex and one needs time and patience to get to know it. To do justice to Une Rose de Kandahar. As beautiful as its name is, I give it the additional name: Atomic Bomb!

Afghanistan … a beleaguered but still fascinating country with so many facets. I have not been there yet, and I do not plan to go there anytime soon; who could blame me? Yet, what one hears and sees about this mysterious land awakens curiosity and a desire for discovery. So, in this comment, I must let my imagination guide me. In my world of imagination, I am a tourist in a peaceful Afghanistan that I can explore freely and without danger. I take the liberty to fantasize accordingly for this comment - well aware that this fantasy is currently of a utopian nature.

I think of the hospitality and warmth, those character traits that are often said to be innate to the people there, especially to those who have little. I think of the scorching heat that sometimes drives me, as an average Central European, to despair, and how I cling to every water bottle and every piece of fruit to stay hydrated. The locals seemed to understand my suffering and offered me a basket of apricots, a bit of cinnamon, and to have something solid between my teeth, a few bitter almonds, whose aroma came into full bloom while chewing and beautifully accompanied the compote I had made myself, consisting of mashed apricots and cinnamon sticks. I immediately felt better - yes - even invigorated and gastronomically spoiled, and I left the village and its inhabitants to make my way to the next one.

The temperatures gradually dropped. While the days here can be unbearably hot, the nights can also become biting cold. This night was to be one of those. The sky was clear, the stars sparkled, and I saw our Milky Way for the first time. No artificial light, as we know it in our densely populated countries, clouded that atmosphere.
I reached the next village. The moonlight illuminated the large cluster of clay huts in a haunting way, winds blew over the fields, which would again be struck by the glare of the high, hot sun the next day. The closer I got to the clay hut that was designated for my accommodation, the stronger I perceived a floral aroma that must have originated from the accompanying rose garden. Tired from my day trip, I entered this garden full of curiosity. The floral, so dark aroma intensified, flooding my nasal cavities. These roses were not at all fruity, not playful, but mystical, dark, unpretentious, ripe, illuminated by the moon, thorny, dominant, companions of the Afghan night.
Enchanted by that olfactory delight, I entered my accommodation. The village elder was already waiting for me and embraced me warmly, showed me my bed, and promptly left me alone, as he must have recognized upon my entering the hut that my eyes were nearly closing while standing. So I lay down, the roses were to accompany me into sleep together with the freshly harvested tobacco stored in a large sack standing right next to my bed. And so I fell asleep after just a few minutes - almost tipsy from this warming, sweet aura - and was awakened the next morning with tea and a bit of bread. Just the evening before, I had communicated that they need not go to great lengths for me. Nevertheless, they made a great effort with the tea. My guest gift to the village elder was now in that tea they served me - a vanilla tea, whose aroma filled the entire hut, complemented the tobacco, and was subtly accompanied by the rose. All of this evoked associations of cherry tobacco, which, although I am a non-smoker and do not know much about hookahs, made me want to linger longer. It must have been this combination of vanilla and roses that made me smell it this way. Anyway … I did not want to leave here anymore. This warmth, so inviting, so heartfelt, so cozy, held me captive to that place, yet I knew that it would eventually be time to wake up again.
Dear readers,

So this is how Afghanistan smells? Do you know? I do not. That was just a fantasy, trying to obscure all the terrible things in that country. Perhaps I am completely wrong with it, if a fantasy can be wrong, and your associations, images, and ideas, my dear readers, are entirely different. But as I said … it is a fantasy, and so we will leave it at that and perhaps enjoy it together, no matter how utopian it may seem in light of the situation in this mysterious land.

review_title: Un Rose de Kandahar ...... Symphony of Floral-Spicy Abundance .....
review_content:
your spice refines juicy fruits -
your roses enchant the senses -
with you I let myself fall -
onto a soft bed -
of musk and vanilla -

I don't really want to write poetry - - but I am once again enchanted - and more than impressed - -
in this case by a rose scent!! …..
Rose scents ……. actually not my desired fragrance direction - , because they usually come across as too flowery harmless, sweet, and boring ……

Different with this beautiful rose from the Middle East, which, after I have freed it from its Pentagon -, conveys the following to my senses ……

Once you have overcome the few steps from the slightly musty-earthy cellar with large strides and reached the bright garden, whose magnificent roses lean lushly and heavily into the light and impregnate the air along with its full-bodied fruits -, you are reconciled.
Reconciled with the beginning of this fragrance, which might scare some at first …….
I suspect it is the patchouli in the base, which pushes itself dramatically to the forefront for my nose right from the start and creates a typical and often described, slightly musty impression.
In agreement with an immediately present citrus note, it tries to assert itself a bit, but in this intensity it quickly recedes to create a beautiful rounding later in this concert …….

First come the apricots - - then the roses ;)

When I enter this garden after the subjectively perceived musty intermezzo -, I first smell the ripeness of juicy apricots, infused with the aroma of cinnamon and almonds, which somewhat capture the fruitiness of the fragrance and round it off gourmandishly …….. above all, a delicate warm spice hovers - , possibly stemming from the tobacco that deliciously weaves in, the vetiver, and the essential oil of special Afghan roses from the Nangarhar province, which, according to the description, also contributes a certain spicy component with its aroma of spices and plums.

The fantastic interaction of the ingredients listed in the pyramid results in a delicate fruity-powdery, minimally spicy event, in which the softened patch takes on the role of the powdery effect, and in which the wonderful roses secretly frolic …..
secretly - - …. , because they do not predominantly determine the perfume, but rather carry it along cleverly, thus giving the scent a velvety depth and a very noble aura. - - I also believe I can perceive delicate woody notes in between.

Equally at the end of their virtuoso performance, the actors of this magnificent artifact sink under the influence of subtly sweet amber on a powdered soft musk-vanilla cloud and form a fantastic drydown.
And in contrast to my skeptical attitude towards sweet rose waters, this fragrance does not convey the impression of an arbitrary perfume of this species at any stage.

A creation that absolutely enchants unisex and, in its sillage effect, makes a real statement without being overly assertive.
The longevity extends from day into night. And with the warmth of summer days/nights, the fragrance wafts enchants the wearer and their environment even more in my opinion.

Andy Tauer is probably not able to produce this perfume in a consistently uniform quantity - , as the oil of these special roses is not available in unlimited supply ………
therefore - - one should not be afraid of scarcity - and if it pleases - then bunker purchases are worthwhile ;) :)

for the never-ending fragrance concert of the abundance of lush summer gardens ….. :))

How beautiful the ingredient rose is in a perfume, in whatever form, became truly clear to me many years ago when I got to know Zino by Davidoff (the version with italic font before the dilution). There are indeed parallels to Phi - Une Rose de Kandahar. Both share a spicy-oriental character. However, there are also marked differences. Phi is noticeably fruitier and more floral, overall sweeter, and less woody than Zino. Nevertheless, Phi contrasts the floral sweetness with a dark, very oily, slightly bitter, and spicy note. This rose oil-like quality is particularly characteristic. It has almost a medicinal aspect at the beginning, without being sharp. A fabulous Bitter Sweet Symphony.

A connection can also be made to Lumière Noire pour Homme by MFK. This one is certainly lighter, more transparent than Phi, and in its flawlessness also more abstract. LpH is overall fresher. Phi, on the other hand, is more sensual. The fragrance makes no secret of placing the apricot fruit and marzipan right at the center. But only to capture both components with fresh, darkly spicy tobacco. Here, those who can appreciate Tobacco Vanille by Tom Ford might feel addressed. Interestingly, Phi is owned by more men than women on parfumo (as of 03.03.2021). In terms of target group voting, women are proportionally ahead. This reflects a possible gender-specific categorization (for those who wish to use it as a point of reference) of Phi well. It is unisex, remains ambivalent, and somewhat eludes categorization. I find that immensely appealing.

Phi is a spring, autumn, and winter fragrance. And a scent for sleeping. Therefore, references to Oud Satin Mood by MFK are also possible from my perspective, although there is no oud in Phi. The drydown is wonderfully soft, warm, and harmonious. Here, musk, tonka, and amber do a great job, fixing it firmly. However, it is not overly heavy, as one might initially suspect. Projection and longevity are undoubtedly good, but overall, Phi does not come across as overloaded to me. Certainly, one must have an openness to sweetness and gourmand notes. The cliff of over-sentimentality is then skillfully navigated. As for categorizing Phi, I also find that the fragrance is both retro and progressive at the same time. In my view, it is indeed so unique that I can imagine it on both an older woman and a younger man equally. Phi is a perfume that seems to particularly come to life through the wearer. I find that post-post-modern. And utterly delightful.

His name was Bryan. He was a soldier, stationed in Kandahar. His wish was always to do something righteous and serve his country. His parents never wanted him to become a soldier. The dangers and risks he might face were not small.
It happened as it had to happen. The overseas assignment. Kandahar. A province so beautiful and yet marked by so many atrocities.
The people back there were so frightened, and yet so friendly. All they wanted was peace. Peace that everyone should have, regardless of country, religion, or political views. Bryan saw these people for what they were: human beings, and sought closeness. He tried to get to know them and show them that he was not a threat.
Time passed, and trust built up between him and the people. One day, outside of his duty, a village boy wanted to show him something. He led him to a magnificent landscape filled with countless flowers. Among them was a rose, known as the Rose of Kandahar.

This rose would ultimately play a decisive role, but more on that later.

Bryan was more than fascinated. This landscape and the accompanying scent. He was more than taken with it. The rose exuded such a wonderful fragrance that he could hardly put it into words.
At first, he perceived an engaging spicy start, paired with a well-measured sweetness. That must be the cinnamon and bitter almond. A great contrast, as he found. As he let the aromas settle a bit and time went on, he could perceive further notes. Here, it was primarily the tobacco that became increasingly prominent for him. The scent of the rose now also supported this. The fragrance was distinguished by its many facets and dimensions. He could hardly extract everything. It was an opulent work of art, complex and capturing the surroundings around him. In the final moments, it became earthier, with patchouli dominating the scene, and eventually, the scent faded away.
A flattering scent that never veered into sweetness.

Enchanted by this perception, he lost track of time. This scent lingered for so long. An enormous longevity.
He thanked the village boy and asked if he could pick a rose once a month. He wanted to show his wife and parents the incredibly beautiful sides of Kandahar. The boy agreed. A part of the landscape served the population for planting raw materials and crops.

Every month, he now sent his family a postcard with a rose. He told them about the wonderful acquaintances, the surroundings, the culture, the food.
His family was delighted and kept everything. The postcard and the rose, which captured the scent of Kandahar.

At some point, however, the messages stopped coming. The worry and despair turned into bitter certainty. Their son, their husband had fallen. What they had always feared had come to pass. What remained for the family was both the beautiful and the ugly side of Kandahar. The rose, which captured the beauty, and the war, which took it away. The roses remained preserved. As a reminder of the positive that their son had described and as a memory of their son himself.

Life. So beautiful and yet so fleeting. Enjoy it.

Treasures are often not lying around on the street. They need to be sought and found.

Such is the case with PHI, a perfume that was unavailable for a long time and thus difficult to procure. When I finally found a supplier, the shipping was shrouded in mystery. More specifically: shipped with UPS and not delivered to me. Intensive inquiries revealed that the bottle was dropped off at the bicycle shop in our small town.

PHI was a blind buy for me. I had no idea what to expect.

So, I picked it up at the bicycle shop and received a metal canister. What could possibly be inside? Screws and nuts or perhaps a repair kit for bicycle tubes?

The metal box is painted a cool blue on the inside. The unadorned green bottle simply placed inside along with a handwritten card that says “Enjoy! Andy Tauer.

Glue or can I use this to protect the garden fence from rust? Everything somehow fit with and into the bicycle shop.

“We don’t smell like Eau de Toilette
Here we sniff good chain grease” (TORFROCK)

crossed my mind. The bottle hadn’t exactly been cheap.

Nervously, I pressed the spray head and then … Wow, what is this?!!

Unusual, fruity, spicy start.

A mysterious, lush rose follows. I can easily imagine this in a dry and barren landscape.

Woods, vanilla, amber, and who knows what else complement this rose well and lastingly in the base.

Tobacco is listed in the fragrance pyramid. For me, a very often challenging scent component, but it doesn’t bother me in the slightest with PHI. It makes this oriental-influenced fragrance perfect for me.

The large Phi stands
in mathematics for the irrational numerical value of the “golden ratio,”
in electrical engineering and physics for magnetic flux,
in lighting technology for luminous flux,
in chemistry for the volume fraction of a substance in a gas mixture.

The scientist Andy Tauer has created for me with PHI a
innovative,
unusual,
cool,
quirky,
pleasant,
oriental, and
wearable
rose scent
to which the term niche truly applies.

There is an undeniable similarity in concept to “L'Air du Désert Marocain.” If you like No. 02, you should definitely try PHI.

The bottle isn’t exactly cheap - but it is worth the price.

Une Rose de Kandahar is one of the most cuddly, delicious, and beautiful rose interpretations I know, yet it does not conform to any conventions.

Cinnamon, bitter almond, vanilla, tonka, and apricot create the impression of a delicious, oriental pastry, refined with the finest rose oil. The rose does not stand alone in the foreground here, but serves, as it does in some oriental desserts, as a special rounding. Perhaps it is vetiver that makes the rose appear somewhat green in places. I imagine green notes to be somewhat strange in a more or less gourmand fragrance, but here it fits perfectly. When you smell it again on your arm, the rose seems deep dark, warm, and the apricot appears to create a special spiciness together with it.

Une Rose de Kandahar is a unique fragrance full of beauty. Not a trivial rose-oud combination, not a dramatic rose just for women. A fragrance for both men and women, and a rose that even rose haters might enjoy. This masterpiece reminds me with every sniff of original oriental sweets, yet fortunately it is not overly sweet, but instead captures this wonderfully interesting variety and combination of aromas.

Absolutely recommended for testing, and a fragrance that seems worth every cent even at its proud price of 150€/50ml!

review_title: A rose is a rose is a rose!
review_content: The charm of the rose lies not merely in its scent and its appearance but in the fact that anyone who wants to enjoy its beauty and fragrance must also love its thorns. (Daniel Lipp) You are a masterpiece of beauty and handling. You are satisfied with the least. You survive long periods of drought and shine when you receive a few drops of water. You are...

You don't make it easy for me! You are by no means just a rose; you are an entire rose plantation. But you are not alone, around the plantation grow some cinnamon bushes with their fragrant bark, there are large tobacco fields that contribute the robust, aromatic scent of tobacco leaves, and there is plenty of greenery that takes the sweetness away from your lush, large, and strongly scented blooms.

Your name suits you like no other - Kandahar is indeed a very troubled region where many people have lost their lives due to political unrest. It is not easy to cultivate you to the splendor with which you then shine in this beautiful bottle. Kandahar is also quite a dry region, and you do not make it easy for the people there to give you everything you need to thrive; hence, there is only a limited number of your magnificent blooms each year.

Your perfume possesses a sillage that is not to be underestimated and could certainly meet with resistance from people who generally do not like roses. But for those who love you, they can enjoy you for hours on end, completely immersed in your beauty.
For even when you have settled down and rest your head on a bed made of vetiver grass, adorned with delicate slices of vanilla and sprinkled with a dark, warm blend of patchouli, amber, and musk, your strength and beauty can still be felt.

You are not an oriental rose, but a very modern and quite European rose in a very refined combination with a dirty, dark background.

All the effort that people have put into you has paid off, and this unusual perfumer from Switzerland, named Andy Tauer, has succeeded in capturing you in such a fantastic combination in the bottle that you can not only showcase all your beauty but also bring along all the scents of your original environment. And he tries to do this anew every year, bringing a limited number of bottles to us perfume lovers and hoping that he will succeed again next year. That your bottles are always sold out quickly goes without saying.

You are not the most beautiful rose in my rather large collection of rose fragrances, but you are by far the most interesting and sophisticated! I am already looking forward to the 2015 version and am curious whether you will smell the same as this year or bring a variant.

What does the beginner do to gain experience? Right, she sniffs here and there, reads through various descriptions and comments, picks out what she finds interesting, and ends up more or less accidentally with the Rose of Kandahar.
I love roses; my garden is adorned with about twenty of these beauties, and each one smells better than the other. I value that; the modern stuff that looks nice but is completely scentless does not come into my house. 'Une Rose de Kandahar' is certainly not modern stuff, even though the perfume hasn't been around for long. As powerful and massive as it comes, it seems to have sprung straight from the fifties, when sex bombs like Bardot, Loren, or Monroe set the tone. Its fragrance orgy is like these ladies: lush, sensual, and with an all-dominating presence.
The first impression after spraying? Intense! ... a brief recoil ... cautiously sniffing again ... still intense! I don't really find anything fresh or bergamot-like; the apricot is also well hidden, probably too shy to come out among all the powerful floral queens. I can't detect the vetiver that I love so much anywhere, neither at the beginning nor at the end. Instead, a flood of roses takes your breath away, because this flood is not sweet-smelling like my garden roses; it is dark and heavy, bitter and smoky.
Not suitable for everyday wear, and it has clearly and distinctly made me understand that I am not made for such heavyweights. But despite everything, compliments for this powerful scent and congratulations to all who can wear this rose.

review_title: La Fleur que tu m´avais jetée...
review_content: "Look how I have carried the flower close to my heart since that day, - although it withered in the dull air, its sweet scent remained! In captivity, in sleepless hours, through it I found my way to you, in this scent you were so near, that even at night I could only see you. It urged me to accuse you, a powerless hatred made me ask: what have I done to you, oh God, that...

review_title: Afghan Rose? Bulgarian Rose? Marzipan Rose!
review_content:
I actually wanted a rose fragrance… But let’s start from the beginning!

It all started when I discovered my love for rose fragrances some time ago. Yes, I know, many people here are now quite fed up with rose scents, but personally, I haven’t had enough of them, or rather, I am still on the lookout for a great men’s rose fragrance. To get straight to the point - “Une Rose de Kandahar” is only partially that.

In the meantime, I have tried quite a few rose fragrances, including many great ones that I can even call my own, such as Halfeti (see my comment on that fragrance). While it is very masculine, I wouldn’t classify it as a classic rose fragrance where the rose would dominate. However, it is very mass-appealing, and I would define it as the more wearable brother of “Viking.” Other rose fragrances, like “Rose Oud” by Kilian or Noir de Noir, I also like very much, but they are a bit too feminine for my taste. Now, onto “Une Rose de Kandahar”…

I had read a lot about this fragrance beforehand and had high hopes that this could be my men’s rose fragrance. So I ordered it here in the souk (thanks to Marcello) and tried it today.

At first, the scent clearly starts out as a rum ball for me, which immediately awakens childhood memories. An unexpected opening, but so far so good. As the top notes develop, more and more gourmand notes come through, a bit of cinnamon and, quite clearly, marzipan, naturally due to the bitter almond. This smells very intense, so much so that one might think they are standing in the kitchen baking a cake with Dr. Oetker’s bitter almond flavoring. If you like this, you’re in for a treat, but it might also put off one or two people.

In the heart note, the rose notes finally come through. Supposedly, all kinds of roses are supposed to be present here - Afghan rose, Bulgarian rose, Bourbon rose geranium… But for me, it is a marzipan rose! This is simply (unfortunately) because the bitter almond never fully retreats, and the various rose accords constantly have to battle against the almond. Sometimes this works better, sometimes less so.

In the base note, a bit more sweetness comes through from the vanilla and tonka bean, but overall, the impression of the marzipan rose remains.

This is very disappointing for me, as I actually wanted a rose fragrance but ended up with almost a gourmand. I should have listened better to the comments here! Don’t get me wrong, the scent is really good and I like it, but it is indeed different from what I had hoped for. The combination of gourmand and rose is certainly interesting and quite successful, but the search for my men’s rose fragrance continues.

The sillage and longevity are very good and, for me, also rather masculine, although the fragrance can certainly be worn by the female gender as well. Like with so many heavy and gourmand fragrances, “Une Rose de Kandahar” feels most at home in autumn and winter and is more suitable for the evening.

In summary, I can say that while I like “Une Rose de Kandahar” and could imagine wearing the fragrance more regularly, it ultimately doesn’t quite make the cut for a top spot with me. To make matters worse, my wife doesn’t like the scent at all, which doesn’t exactly make the search for my perfect men’s rose fragrance any easier…

In the ROSE VON KANDAHAR Une rose de Kandahar, there is a lot of love; I even see a certain resemblance to the famous No.2, of course with a different fragrance pyramid and different ingredients. In terms of "craftsmanship," however, it is comparable to what is personally the best scent from Tauer for me.
Unfortunately, I have only recently acquired this rarity and haven't really dissected it yet. But it is delicious, tasty, and seductively gourmand. I've never had such a delightful rose in my nose.
In the meantime, I must say that Mr. Tauer has achieved something extraordinary here. Not too much or too little of anything. And only the finest. That's how it should be. I am receiving praise everywhere, even though rose has always been somewhat problematic for me. But here, it is one of the most brilliant fragrances from the house of Tauer. I can already see that there is much more to discover. I think I need to get myself another bottle before everything is sold out again for quite a while.

Fragrances can have totally different effects depending on the person. I had such an experience again last week. I love Rose de Kandahar. I perceive the rose only faintly on myself, and the bitter almond doesn't come through at all. Overall, on my skin, it's a dusty, spicy-masculine affair - wonderful! However, I don't dare to wear it around others and always wear it quietly...

I am very enthusiastic about this scent.
Although I am not a big fan of rose fragrances, I love this perfume above all.
When I spray it on, I immediately think of the past, yet not in an old-fashioned way. The scent definitely has a gourmand touch, but it is by no means too sweet or cloying like many other rose fragrances. In my opinion, PHI has a very unisex quality.
The fragrance is therefore a interplay of many contrasts, and that is what makes it so special for me.

Certain roses - like those I knew from my mother's garden - smell unpleasantly intense up close. However, from a distance, they are enchanting and captivating. Many perfumes with rose as the main component often do not necessarily smell like a classic rose and tend to be rather subdued regarding the characteristic notes.

Not so with this one.

At the start, the fragrance components listed in the top notes, apart from bitter almond, are hardly noticeable. From the heart note onward, the rose-heavy composition unfolds gradually. Neither captivating, nor flattering, nor striking, and not even refined. Rather, it is simply exhausting, uneven, dissonant, and disharmonious. At times, the accords were perceived as slightly synthetic.

Even the well-perceptible tobacco (or tobacco leaf) is, despite the contributing spiciness, not a suitable antagonist. Coarse power without balance does not quite work.
Personally, I appreciate a fragrance with edges and corners that give it individuality and character. The perfume fails to skillfully unfold along the narrow path without appearing pompous, overwhelming, or opulent.

Only after many hours does the very pleasant, creamy, and successful base, primarily consisting of amber and musk, become noticeable. Longevity is impeccable. However, that is not enough compensation.

For me, this composition is too unbalanced. Especially in the middle part, I find it desirable to adjust the volume a bit with a different composition. It can remain (very) strong, but it should form a balanced whole with the rose in the leading role without the current intensity. And perhaps include one or two antagonists. If reformulated, I would be willing to try it again.

I really like "Au Coeur du Désert | Tauer Perfumes." With this fragrance, I have the association of 'working in a dusty attic, then freshly showered and moisturized, enjoying the evening in the shade.'

With PHI, it's similar. Only that here I smell an almond croissant the whole time - even while tidying up in the dusty attic.

What also accompanies me after finishing work and showering - yes, showered and moisturized, the cream has a very subtle almond scent. And subtle mineral notes - I think this association comes from the combination of cinnamon and tobacco.

What I hardly perceive or only very subtly in the background is rose... :)

In any case, rose or not, I smelled it and was immediately smitten, and I still am, great fragrance!

Une Rose de Kandahar truly impressed me, as this Andy Tauer is more than just a simple rose fragrance. It possesses a wonderful marzipan-like (that is, almondy) note that makes it something special and seems to set it apart from other rose perfumes.

Here you find a blend of bitter almond, apricot, cinnamon, various types of roses, tobacco, vanilla, even tonka bean, and much more. This combination creates a seductive yet subtle sweetness, accompanied by a finely-spiced nuance. The spiciness, however, is expressed in a subtle and elegant manner.

The roses do not simply come across as floral; rather, they have this unmistakable marzipan aroma that gives the perfume a certain depth. It is a type of rose that you don't smell every day and that - one should know - not everyone would wear. It is a scent for confident women who enjoy exploring new fragrance worlds and wish to radiate a touch of elegance and sophistication. It is not a typical everyday scent, but rather something for special occasions or unique moments.

The longevity and sillage of this Tauer are decent. You only need a few sprays, and the fragrance lasts long on the skin, unfolding its scent journey over the course of wearing it.

What I also appreciate about Une Rose de Kandahar is that a considerable amount of natural fragrance materials were likely used in its creation. This gives the perfume a vibrant and authentic quality that is often missed in many mainstream scents.

Overall, I can recommend this perfume if you are looking for an extraordinary and unique rose fragrance. Give it a try and let yourself be enchanted by the fascinating combination of gourmand rose and fine-spicy sweetness!

For anyone looking for a fragrance that combines roses and almonds, "Collectible PHI - Une Rose de Kandahar | Tauer Perfumes" is the right choice. The longevity on my skin is about 12 hours with a successful sillage. The top note starts off floral, soapy, sweet, and powdery with a lot of rose water. This rose aroma becomes more intense in the heart note, accompanied by fruity...

review_title: A unique, masterful interpretation of "Blue" with real ambergris - a masterpiece
review_content:
Ambre Bleue, an outstanding masterpiece by Vincent Micotti, is a charismatic and distinctive fragrance with a fascinating personality. As the name suggests, the scent captures various facets of "Blue": the ocean, the wind, the sky, and their intoxicating nuances.

In contrast to most fragrances that dedicate themselves to the theme of "Blue" and associate "Blue" with fresh, aquatic notes and occasionally fruity or salty accents, Ambre Bleue offers a completely independent interpretation. It is vibrant, profound, and beautifully unexpected, an extraordinary sensory experience.

Although real ambergris, the "bluest" of all ingredients, is used generously, the fragrance does not feel heavy; instead, it radiates a special clarity and timeless elegance. Ambre Bleue captivates and unfolds an irresistible sensuality that is hard to resist.

"Who would think that the finest ladies and gentlemen indulge in a fragrance derived from the unglamorous intestines of a sick sperm whale! And yet, it is so. Gray amber is considered by some to be the cause and by others the result of poor digestion that whales sometimes suffer from. How such dyspepsia could be cured is hard to say, unless one administers three or four boatloads of rhubarb pills to the patient and then quickly gets out of the line of fire […] I assert: When the sperm whale thrusts its tail high, it emits just as much fragrance as a musk-scented lady rustling her skirts in a warm salon." Excerpt from the book by Herman Melville: Moby Dick Chapter 92 - Ambergris

For centuries, if not millennia, wild stories have surrounded this mysterious substance. In the Chinese Empire, amber was referred to as "lung sien hiang," or the "saliva perfume of dragons," until about 1000 AD, as it was believed that the substance originated from the saliva of dragons sleeping on rocks by the sea. In the Orient, amber is still known by this name today. It was not until 1574 that the Flemish botanist Carolus Clusius was the first to deduce from the inclusions of cuttlefish beaks in amber that it comes from the digestive tract of whales. However, this went largely unnoticed for a long time. Only later, when fresh amber was discovered in the intestines of individual sperm whales during slaughter, was Clusius' statement confirmed
**

But now to the scent:
For me, it starts with a generous portion of spices in the form of cardamom and pepper. This spiciness is by no means nose-wrinkling strong; rather, it paves the way for the olfactory experience that is yet to come. The main player in this masterpiece by Vincent Micotti is, as could be expected, the natural ambergris. According to YS-Uzac, Ambre Bleue contains a generous amount of the precious whale secretion. After about five minutes, a bright, radiant, aquatic, slightly animalistic note emerges that must inevitably come from the ambergris. I also perceive the exotic resins mentioned in the fragrance pyramid quite strongly. These hold all the fragrance notes together, so to speak, with their sticky quality, ensuring that the spices and the slightly animalistic ambergris never become unpleasant for the nose. In the base, leather, oud, and incense hide, but they do not overpower; rather, they form a worthy foundation for the royal ambergris. All in all, it can be said that Ambre Bleue, due to the amount of ambergris used, conveys a natural aquatic impression throughout the entire fragrance journey, where initially the spices and towards the end the dark woody notes, as well as leather and incense, play a rather subordinate role. The whole is then enveloped in a warm resinous cloak that embraces all the fragrance notes. In my opinion, we are dealing with a masterpiece of perfumery that can bring much joy to a trained nose.

review_title: When the violet meets the almond...
review_content:
When the shy and tender violet meets the sweet Almond , the result is a perfect scented marriage: this eau is very light and pure, clean and minimalist, but also extremely feminine and charming in its simplicity.
The violet note is just suggested, not too vibrant and intoxicating and its shy character is strenghtened by a warmer and sweeter Almond note, giving that "floriental" touch to this scented water.
It's a perfume to wear by day, at the office too because it's very soft and inoffensive. It's perfect in every season but mainly in spring-summer . In my opinion, it's one of the best scented waters made by the good Italian brand Collistar.The price for a 100ml size is quite affordable. about 40€ and you can buy online too.
if you're searching somethoing which makes you feel good and sexy but with dicretion, give a chance to this scent!

This is powerful stuff.
Cumin and fresh, cut and dried tobacco u can smell pretty good.
I detect a little bit fruitiness also, a strange strawberry note, could be my nose.
Performance is great, stays long and has pretty powerful sillage.
This is quite potent and strong, not recommended for the younger crowd and for the Western nose it could be too much.
Overall quite unique smell and also some similarities to Rasasi Shuhrah as Mihaiu said, for me mainly the tobacco smell.

Can four listed components capture a state of mind, indeed a character trait?
And can they olfactorily trace the urge to roar out a deeply seated tension in the shabby short window of confined freedom?

Two questions are posed to the second man in the fragrance series, and he will answer them convincingly.

Here now is the apparent discord of an agitated time span.

Hiss!

Resinous benzoin in the greeting.
Today easily found in oriental fragrances, in 1982 it meant the ultimate slap in the face.
Buddy, open your eyes wide!

Certainly, a certain citrusy undertone with spectral, herbal aspects shows thoughtful craftsmanship. But what matters here is the rough wooden nature.
Can't you see the forest for the trees?

This resin is illuminated in such a way that its sweet side completely disappears into the shadows.
Slightly salty, a bead of good amber will make it combative.
Hunter's fences want to be jumped, and a high seat ascended.
The gaze sharpens.
Watch out, my friend!

Once at the top, then the introspection.
Cultivated animalic warmth crawls up the leather jacket.
Nature has been tamed, that's just how it is.
Bright oak moss with a hint of sorrel freed the pores of the skin to naturally draw out that spicy masculinity from the body's glands.
The solid emphasis of the body.
The tightrope act of rutting self-control.
The social acceptance of the three-day beard.

That the fragrance does not drift into unrestrained brutality is thanks to a noble iris.
German bearded iris?
Quite possible.
But it is not her lovely floral lilac that conveys here, no, it is her rhizome from which something precious is extracted.
Soothing, nurturing confidence, the divine messengers accompany the second man.
Slightly powdery, subtly floral, and with a hint of golden amber.
The emotional state is ordered and calmed.

There he stands now, full of inner turmoil and composed.

For this is how the fragrance will settle, balancing the harsh contrasts.

With the aforementioned limited time window, I mean that mood of the period from 1982 to 1984.
Much change was in the air.
Not only the replacement of Helmut Schmidt and the confirmation of Helmut Kohl, the nuclear armament, the initial digitalization, and the accompanying changed production process.
A certain neuromantic urge and quest for freedom spread along forest-lined country roads.
The motorcycle achieved cult status.
And in leather gear, even if just a leather jacket, one could endure along the fir green, finding oneself again.

Aside from the lovely NDW - Neue Deutsche Welle - Spliff created a different and deeper understanding of the current events for a brief moment.
Their song "Herzlichen Glückwunsch" illustrates for me the inner soul of Man Two.
The video could not be more fitting.

With what exquisite range of grooming products this magnificent fragrance was equipped is best described by Lancaster85 in his review.
Back then, all fragrances by Jil Sander were produced in Wiesbaden.

As fashionable as the 1980s decade was, the market presence of the second man remained short-lived.

But fortunately, the urge for the forest was not subjected to a fleeting trend.
And that man could once again enchant with his romantic side today.

review_title: The Probably Most Unknown and Rarest Jil Sander Fragrance
review_content:
Jil Sander Man II by Jil Sander is a perfume from the Woody Chypre fragrance family. Jil Sander Man II was launched in 1982. It had the same design as the previous Jil Sander Pure for Men, except that its packaging was gray instead of black, the bottle was transparent instead of darkened, and the cap was gray instead of black.

This fragrance, which is very atypical for Jil Sander, contains iris, oak moss, benzoin resin, and castoreum.

Benzoin is used in perfume making; it is particularly suitable for oriental and warm fragrance compositions, and it also serves as a fixative. The scent of benzoin is sticky, intensely balsamic, slightly chocolaty, and definitely reminiscent of vanilla. Benzoin or benzoin resin refers to the resin (the flowing gum) of various benzoin trees.

Castoreum, also known as beaver musk, is a secretion from the glandular sacs of beavers. The secretion consists of a complex mixture of chemical compounds that are likely formed from secondary metabolites of urine. The beaver uses the fatty secretion for fur care and to mark its territory. In perfumery, castoreum, which is said to have an aphrodisiac (erotic) effect, is a component of some fragrances. Similar substances are now produced synthetically.

Oak moss, the typical fragrance ingredient of chypre scents, which originated in Cyprus and was first developed by François Coty in 1917, rounds off the fragrance and gives it a spicy freshness.

Overall, it is a fragrance composition of smoky benzoin resin, erotic balsamic castoreum, and fresh spicy oak moss. And that is exactly how it smells; I consider myself a lucky owner of the EdT. It starts intensely spicy-woody and develops into a balsamically warm scent within 20 minutes. I would recommend it as an autumn-winter fragrance for real men! This scent reflects pure rugged masculinity. I personally find it very unique, very intensely smoky-balsamic; I can only imagine wearing it on cold winter days.

In the original leaflet for the fragrance, it was described as follows:
"Consistently masculine scent. Characterized by self-awareness and dynamism. Elegant through its herb-fresh aroma. Jil Sander/ Man Two is exclusivity and vitality. Simply extraordinary."

Even in the woody-spicy 80s, it was too extraordinary; this also became its downfall at the end of the 80s, six years after its release, as it disappeared quietly from perfumeries.

Even in the early 80s, the grooming-conscious man was offered quite a bit:
Eau de Toilette Splash
Eau de Toilette
Pre Shave
After Shave
After Shave Balm
Gentle Shaving Foam
Active Face Moisturizer
Deodorant Spray
Deodorant Stick
Moisturizing Body Cream
Refreshing Shower Gel
Refreshing Body Splash
Refreshing Body Lotion
Bath Soap

Some information from my Douglas magazine from 1981/1982:
Eau de Toilette 60ml 40DM
After Shave 60ml 30DM
Bath Soap 150gr. 20DM
Shower Gel 200ml 38DM
Moisturizing Body Cream 100ml 30DM
Deodorant Stick 100ml 28DM

review_title: I hate myself for loving you
review_content:
Man II as well. Damn, where are you? Jil Sander Man, which everyone here calls Man pure, has accompanied me as my scent for many years. Man II completely slipped through my fingers in the 80s. Unfortunately! I wish I had never met you! It happened as it had to happen. We did meet. Resiny and light brown you are. With a fine note of cognac, you have burned yourself into my memory.
While Jil Sander's Man (pure) is a wonderful reminder of past times, you are the scent I would still spray on myself every day today. I know nothing comparable.
This gem is as rare as the legendary Patou. Simply untraceable. Probably only to be found in estate sales. At flea markets, for little money, because the poor sellers have no idea what treasure they possess!
My life must go on without you... damn!
Released in 1982, Jil Sander Man II was not a great success. In the same decade, it disappeared without a trace. Yet it still has its loyal fans today. Myself included.

I’m going to listen to the fitting song by Joan Jett 10 more times now. After that, John Waite, Missing you.
Drink: Royal Bermuda Yacht Club

Conclusion: Irreplaceable!

I am a fan of Jil Sander and have tested most of her fragrances. Besides the great Man Pure (her first men's fragrance) and the mysterious Background, I also quite liked Sander for Men and Sun Men.
I have had this one as a miniature for some time and have worn it a few times. Somehow, I haven't found a way to connect with it yet. I am fascinated by its uncompromising nature and awkwardness, and I will try to convey this impression.

Scent development:
It starts off intensely resinous, with a slight herbal undertone. This resinous impression is very intense and quite off-putting and requires some getting used to for me. However, it is not dark and heavy, but very clear, slightly ethereal, and thus quite biting. Just like the very restrained herbal impression, I also perceive a slightly dirty-animalistic base note that further supports this awkwardness.
There is no development. The scent remains as it started.
I would place the scent most closely in the forest when the air is heavy with resin. However, this doesn't fully capture it, and I can't draw any further fitting analogy. Therefore, it is difficult for me to grasp and categorize. It is absolutely independent and does not care about conventions. In my opinion, Man Two is rough, rather signaling distance, and can only be worn by a very self-confident man.
In its own way, it is fascinating, but for me, it is too awkward and intense.

Longevity and sillage:
The longevity for me is about 8 hours of good perceivability, and the sillage is noticeable almost the entire time, but not too strong.

Bottle:
I like the clear shape of the bottle designed by Peter Schmidt with the two stacked cubes. The color definitely matches the resinous-clear scent impression. The light gray color of the screw cap is something to get used to.

Conclusion:
Resinous-clear, slightly ethereal-biting scent of high intensity. It will certainly deter many and is a clear, uncompromising statement. Due to its creation in the 80s (1982), it has quite a punch. It fits into the typical Sander line of men's fragrances due to its clarity and lack of sweetness (there are few exceptions like Feeling Man). I wouldn't wear it, but I am happy to have an unturned miniature and can occasionally sniff it to then indulge in a pinch with a puzzled smile and think: "Wow, that's bold!" :)

among Jil Sander men's fragrances, I would spontaneously title Jil Sander's second men's scent.

Jil Sander's long-time friend, the Hamburg designer Peter Schmidt, is once again responsible for the design.

As for the fragrance itself, there are currently no offers on the WWW - so I am proud to have received a sample from Ingepetra...merci!

The scent is a classic fougère and reflects a rugged masculinity!

The opening is fresh and green. The progression is spicy, mossy - even smoky.
I detect parallels to Chanel's Antaeus and Scent 79.
However, Jil Sander's Man II is not as dark...

Overall, an interesting fragrance that I personally would not wear.
Nevertheless, it would be appropriate for the Jil Sander company to bring a similar perfume back to the market for the "established" man, as currently there are only sweet, soft men's fragrances from Jil Sander. Scent 79 is, to my knowledge, limited and can only be found in selected perfumeries...

review_title: Green Resinous Leather Powder, Extra Mossy!!
review_content: After I found the "women's fragrance" from Jil Sander in a similar bottle so super cool, I have now come across something equally great "for men." Although I couldn't care less about whether it's for women or men, because I wear what I like anyway. And this one is super cool. Purely subjective! And once again a flea market find. From this afternoon. A chunky "mini" with 10 ml...

review_title: Fly me to the moon with the fragrance rocket from Jil
review_content: Fragrance lovers, I can share this as a prologue: I am the happy owner of this power fragrance. Resinous and smoky, the scent of the rocket's nozzles lies like that of a journey to the moon, which unfortunately did not return. What a shame for a fragrance of this unforgettable mixture of adventure and coziness, which tells legends around the campfire in good company....

A huge thank you to Skylab for the sample of this phantom. Those who think Jil Sander Man, Feeling Man, or Background are rare and scarce - they probably haven't heard of Man II. And that's not only because it has been discontinued for over 20 years, but also because there is simply little demand from fans. Therefore, unlike the rest, there are hardly any eBay listings - this...

Well, actually I love vanilla! Pure by DKNY is the perfect vanilla for me.
Delicious Vanilla was a blind buy and also a mistake. That's not how I want vanilla to be; it comes across as dirty and outdated to me.
Since I haven't quite figured out which ingredients I like, I guess it might be the amber?
The scent doesn't change at all from the beginning to the end.
If someone wants it, please!

Gale Hayman, along with her husband, founded a very successful boutique named Giorgio Beverly Hills in 1961 in Beverly Hills. In 1981, the couple launched a fragrance of the same name, which found enormous appeal in the world of the rich and beautiful. In 1987, the company was acquired by Avon, and Gale established Gale Hayman Inc. From then on, she successfully launched various fragrances under her own name.
The characteristic bottle of the Delicious line is shaped like a stylized rock, with a snow leopard lurking on it, and was nominated for a FiFi award.

With the hit Giorgio Beverly Hills in mind, I was very curious about how the theme of vanilla would be approached, a note that gains significance in autumn and winter and is often too intense and thus unbearable for me in many fragrances.
Delicious Vanilla gets straight to the point, opening with a bright, fine, and delicate vanilla. The fluffy and soft impression is created in combination with the light almond note of heliotrope, yet vanilla remains the defining element throughout, even as the flowers timidly and ethereally join in after about half an hour. I believe I can identify jasmine and sweet pea.
Towards the end, musk gains significance with a soapy component.
Since Delicious Vanilla stays very close to the skin and I can hardly perceive it from 30 cm away, there is little danger of overwhelming myself or my surroundings. Despite this weak projection, it lasts on me for 6-8 hours.

Given the price-performance ratio, you can't go wrong with Delicious Vanilla, and I would definitely recommend a test to friends who enjoy subtle, preferably monothematic vanilla fragrances. The bottle is also a true delight to hold, easy to handle, and a feast for the eyes as well.

After I already had "Delicious" at home, I thought this one would definitely blow me away; but it doesn’t!
This is actually a light vanilla scent that can be worn during the day and in the summer without the people around you having to fan themselves.

The scent progression is quite linear; it’s a mix of "light vanilla," I don’t know how else to express it, and flowers. However, it never becomes heavy or cloyingly sweet, but always remains pleasantly fragrant; a bit playful and naive. Definitely something for younger girls too!

A pleasant light fragrance, just right for warm summer/spring days. It reminds me a lot of the scent Selection by S. Oliver. The fruity accent of apple and the floral note of violet come through very strongly here. The scent smells the same after half an hour as it did at the beginning. Conclusion: not a very extravagant fragrance but very pleasant.

I think this is the perfect summer perfume. The yellow bottle and the fruity-fresh scent lift your spirits and refresh you. I immediately fell in love with the fragrance while testing it at dm and took home a 40 ml bottle right away! Despite its lightness, the longevity is very good, and the bottle doesn’t feel cheap despite its simplicity. I am totally thrilled to have gotten such a great Eau de Toilette for the affordable price!
I also have to say that I’m usually not a fan of sporty - light scents and rarely buy drugstore perfumes.
But here, in my opinion, Puma has hit the mark perfectly!

Okay, okay. It’s warm, it’s humid, and who doesn’t have a citrus craving in this weather! Besides, I like citrus, even in freezing temperatures. Therefore, my assessment will be rather biased and quite favorable.

Sure: Puma hasn’t revolutionized the citrus fruit here. Within a select collection of fine hesperid fruits, this scent will look silly (and smell even sillier). A lot of synthetic, lemon cake batter-like citrus, typical Puma flowers, a bit of friendly cedar, something else, something else. So: Necessary?

Yes, no, maybe. Because: First of all, this is a SPORT scent. An unpretentious little diesel for the gym bag! For those brief moments after the refreshing anti-coma shower. If you expect more here, you should pay attention to the label: PUMA. Hello? They make sports shoes...

Secondly, a small bottle that matches the shower gel and body lotion makes perfect sense (for after sports, of course). From experience, Puma scents as shower gel and lotion are much better, tastier, and more expressive than as EdT. Just look at "Puma Jamaica 1 + 2". So why not take the whole set home?

Unless you want to be politically correct. Then keep your hands off. See below for Turandot!

Before I delve into the fragrance, I want to warn every environmentally conscious person to avoid using the above link: "Free fragrance sample available here." Go to Müller or your nearest department store and test the scent. I did it, ordered the sample, and today I received a postcard by airmail from Hong Kong (!) with a sachet stuck on it. There’s hardly a way to release more unnecessary CO2 into the atmosphere than this. The sachet doesn’t contain a soaked cloth as is often the case, but when you tear it open, about 1/2ml of fragrance splashes out at you.

The fragrance itself is exactly as one would expect. Fresh, floral, citrusy, fruity, and a bit playful. A nice scent for young girls, who can still be kept away from Lady Million. Nothing more, nothing less. However, I find the Esprit and S.Oliver fragrances to be much better for this target group, as they are not quite as banal.

We won’t have to linger long with Yellow, because as quickly as the Puma fragrances are thrown onto the market, they disappear just as fast. But my aversion to P&G has grown even larger with this test. Not because of the fragrance, but - see title.

review_title: A journey through a deep forest
review_content:
The first spray struck me like an unexpected chord: warm, bright, and strangely familiar, yet entirely new. It was as though I had pressed my face against a piece of wood, its grain soaked in a mysterious liquid where citrus seemed woven into its very DNA. A soft sweetness floated alongside, but not the sugar-coated kind; this sweetness had roots, as if it had blossomed from the heart of a flower or the sap of a living stem.

For the first hour, it danced on my skin with that lively citrus glow. the, slowly, it began to shift. The sweetness dimmed, and cedarwood stepped forward, carrying with it the fresh, almost dewy scent of roses just cut from their stems.

By the time the fragrance settled, it had transformed entirely. Vetiver rose from the base like dry grass after rain, entwined with the deep green shadows of oakmoss. Vanilla whispered in the background: subtle, restrained, not the quiet, raw scent of the vanilla pod itself, still clinging to the earth that nourished it.

It is a journey that begins with light, passes through wood and bloom, and ends where soil meets the sky.

A cool breeze blows in an otherwise sun-warmed environment - and it feels good! It comes directly from the forest and carries its herbaceous-green scents. I sit on a bench at the edge of the forest, refreshing myself with a bottle of homemade, real lemonade. With a good book on my lap, not just focused on the text, my gaze wanders everywhere.
Behind the bench, a thick tuft of herb-scented grasses - bright and slightly earthy at the same time. A bit deeper in the forest, moss-covered trunks. Delicately carved silver-green tendrils of oak moss hang down from branches and twigs..
In the clearing before me, lush green herbs grow, exuding a fresh, herbaceous-minty scent, along with some wild roses, whose delicate fragrance wafts over to me from time to time. Otherwise, the woody-aromatic scents of pines, cedars, and firs prevail. In the midst of it all, a small grove of birches. The white bark releases lightly peppery-scented resins with a delicate vanilla note.
Moisture from the last rain has settled as tiny droplets on everything.
Hearty and wonderfully herb-sweet, a sunny autumn day greets.

review_title: I am in the countryside and have an appointment…
review_content:
… with a carpenter who is supposed to make a chest for my perfume atomizers, and he is located right in the middle of the countryside. On the way there, you pass by orange and lemon trees that release their freshness. When I enter the workshop, I get a whiff of pepper in my nose. The young carpenter smiles at me and explains that this comes from the wood. Other woods also blend in. I show him my idea, and he says we can make it happen.

When applying this fragrance, the first thing you notice is a fresh, citrusy, peppery scent. Here, woody and floral accords mix in. The patchouli adds a deep darkness to this perfume. There are also green notes. A hint of vanilla is noticeable, but only very faintly in the background. The vetiver gives us a dry freshness, and the scent is extremely masculine. It vaguely reminds me of Perseus by PMF.

The longevity and sillage are good.

Here we have something different from the house of Lattafa than the usual sweet oriental fragrances. This very masculine scent is something for men from their mid-twenties. I simply cannot imagine it on women, no matter how hard I try. But as always, please try it for yourself. It is also a fresh scent that is an all-rounder, suitable for wearing all year round. During the day, it works just as well at university, in the office, in the workshop, over coffee, or while shopping, as it does in the evening at the theater, in a bar, in a club, in a disco, or at a party.

Anyone looking for a fresh, citrusy, peppery, woody, floral, green, deep, dark, dry scent should take a closer look at this one for a small price.

is exactly what this fragrance smells like, and it's STRONG in the opening. The tartness and creaminess comes together to create a comforting yogurt scent that's more realistic than I ever thought possible. However, if, like me, you don't find the thought of smelling like a dairy product appealing, this scent isn't for you. The longevity was quite average on me, with the scent drying down to a more generic sweetness within a couple of hours. The musk note also began to dominate in this phase.

review_title: Pineapple yogurt turns into a fruity, powdery dessert with a synthetic edge
review_content:
Obtained a decant through a trusted Facebook fragrance group member with whom I've gotten a few decants from. Never thought I'd get to smell Nota Sugar since it's not sold through retailers I buy from, but I've seen it floating around social media so I was curious to get my hands on it.

The beginning is delicious. It smells like vanilla yogurt with good, sizeable chunks of freshly cut pineapple. Sweet, fresh, fruity and really nice to smell. I think the coconut is providing that creamy, lactonic twist that makes it smell like a vanilla yogurt. I barely smell any caramel, although it seems to provide some sweetness. As the perfume moves forward, I get the tangy raspberry note in the background, supporting the fruity vibe of the scent. Almond praliné is powdery and sugary. Even though the vanilla is found in the middle notes, I find that it permeates the whole fragrance with its lovely sweetness. At this point, the scent becomes a little more synthetic than what I wished for. At the edge, there's also the ghost of the functional aspect of sunscreen. It still smells sweet and fruity, but there's the powderiness that also comes through (which is less my thing). Pineapple smells a little more grounded, almost grilled like on a BBQ. The bottom notes further reinforce the sweet and powdery notes in this fragrance as it dies down to a powdery, musky vanilla with an evanescent accord of fruitiness.

I'm glad I got a decant so I could try it, but it won't make it as a full bottle in my collection. It's a different interpretation of a warm weather fragrance made with fruits and sweetness, but the evolution of the perfume is not really my thing. I loved how the pineapple and raspberries paired well together. I did enjoy wearing it and sniffing it throughout the day, so I'll gladly be using up my decant up until the end.

review_title: Pineapple with caramel in front of Copacabana beach
review_content:
tested using a sample, I noticed that this perfume was being mentioned more and more on social networks, so I decided to test it out of curiosity.

it is a gourmand and sweet perfume. I had the impression of being in a palace kitchen surrounded by great starred chefs preparing a magnificent exotic dessert based on roasted pineapple as is done in Brazil with an addition of caramel.

a pleasant and natural smell of worked caramel, far from all those perfumes with cloying synthetic odors. the trail is incredible and the lasting power is impressive.

The perfume lasted 20 hours on my skin, the smell began to fade after 3 hours.

a touch of vanilla and coconut are felt afterwards, prolonging my travel immersion in an exotic country, I had the impression of being on a terrace by the sea and eating this succulent dessert.

The smell is unlike any perfume I have tried so far. Notice to all fans of gourmet perfumes, this perfume is made for you.

product_name: By Night One Way, by Day Another
review_content:
This aftershave is publicly owned by only two users here in this forum, there are no reviews or statements about it, not even a rating. This product really doesn't deserve that, so I will step in and give the aftershave a bit more attention and love.

Olfactorily, one can read the crucial points in the short review of the Eau de Cologne by Byravit. The scent is citrusy, spicy, and a bit woody, making it overall very fresh and - since it is ultimately a functional fragrance as an aftershave - refreshing. The level of aggression after shaving is about medium: there are milder, but also significantly more aggressive aftershaves after shaving. It forgives minor shaving accidents but also reveals the weaknesses of the last shave, if any. The bottle is simple, classic, and allows for the application of a slightly larger amount, if desired.

The longevity and sillage are not bad for an aftershave at all; I use a generous amount of it. Since the scent is very similar to the EdC, apart from the concentration of course, it can be very well paired with its big brother.

My routine is as follows:
1.) After shaving, the aftershave
2.) As an aftershave balm, I use the inexpensive and odorless Penaten oil (500 ml bottle)
3.) With a bit of time in between, then as an olfactory and dermatological revival, the EdC from Lider.

After about 2 - 3 hours, enough time has passed to dedicate oneself to the perfume of the day or evening.

Conclusion: A good, refreshing aftershave, available at a low price, with sufficiently good sillage and longevity, unfortunately probably totally underrated. Just give it a try.

P.S.: For the wet shavers among us, here's a tip that there is also a nice shaving cream from Lider.

So far, all attempts to compare this "Scherrer" with another fragrance have failed. Only "4711," one of the oldest "eau de colognes" still available, bears a slight resemblance to this. "Comes from the neroli and the galbanum"!!! That's what I claim now. And from the mint and the woods. But the Scherrer is "icy-dry," while "4711" is refreshingly cool.
Yes, it is the "dryness," the lemon-tea-like frozen quality that seems to come from the freezer at minus 20 degrees Celsius, that no perfumer has achieved so far. And that means a lot in the confusing, nearly inexhaustible flood of fragrances vying for the noses of customers. Niche! Absolutely! And incredibly green - but not "synthetic." Only much later in the development does "Pop Delights 01" seem to thaw a bit. The "sun of orange blossoms" almost manages it... but not completely. Before it could become "liquid" - late in the "afternoon," the sunset soon breaks in and conjures a mélange of green-yellow-orange ice crystals against the darkening sky. Inimitable and wonderfully unique - like so much from "Scherrer"...

I stumbled upon this fragrance online by chance. It has a tangy, very lemony, and fresh scent. For anyone still searching for a perfume that smells similar to Delial, I highly recommend this fragrance. Every time I wear it, I am reminded of my youth, and that is lovely.

Boy, this is so animalic. Dirty, dirty, dirty. Lovers of animalic scents will adore this perfume because that is what hit me on first spray. It does lighten up as the fragrance progresses, but it is always there right below the surface.

I have a vintage curvy bottle from Revlon with a gold image of an almost naked man and woman on the front of the bottle seated facing each other entwined in an embrace. SEX is what the image implies. Civet, animalic musk, castoreum, and indolic jasmine enforce that image. Intimate is just a nicer way to describe it.

Speaking of the bottle, just from looking at that alone, it's clear this was made in an age when even drugstore buys could exude some semblance of sophistication. (Word of warning about the sprayer though, it shoots out like a fire hose.) It's also clear the juice was made with better quality ingredients than many perfumes today.

The sandalwood is real here, not that synthetic stuff used nowadays in too many perfumes. It's a nice woody sandalwood too, beautifully blended in a resinous elixir of powdery rose, creamy gardenia, dirty jasmine and musk, highlighted with a light dusting of spice and a dose of civet. All is anchored on a bed of oakmoss and amber. Though classified a chypre, it comes across as an oriental to me, in the same way Dioresscence (classified by many as a chypre, but as an oriental on Dior's site) does. That spicy resinous texture gives that impression. This fragrance also reminds me of Tabu, but whereas that fragrance is syrupy, heavy, and I find oppressive, this is lighter, more polished, and refined. Tabu also lacks the sexy animal elements so prominent here. I'm not saying they aren't in Tabu, just that I cannot smell them in the same way I can here – front and center! Intimate seems to be nearer to what the creator of Tabu, (if stories are to be believed), thought (knew?) how a lady of the evening smelled. But in this case, she'd be a high-priced call girl who plays the stock market by day.

Would I wear this fragrance outdoors? Not on your life. I'd be afraid I'd be followed by wolves, both the two-legged and four-legged kind. Still, it was fun to experience this little time capsule in history and to marvel at how daring and glamorous women used to be.

I can still remember it very well. In the late 80s, these small pocket atomizers filled with perfume, resembling BIC lighters, appeared in some supermarkets, somewhere between tobacco and impulse items.

There were four different colors as well as fragrance directions (2 x feminine, 1 masculine, and 1 x unisex), and great luxury was promised at a low price. In principle, not a bad idea, but the core competency of the French BIC company lies in manufacturing ballpoint pens (exactly - those transparent hexagonal ones) and lighters (typically in the oval shape), not in creating perfumes, even if they are supposedly of the finest French quality.

BIC Homme No 1 suggests a masculine direction with a decent swing of sandalwood plus woody notes, a lot of oriental embellishments, and some green notes. Whether this can really be classified as fern, I doubt. Thus, Homme No 1 also captures the virtues of the 80s quite well, albeit more from the less tasteful side of that decade.

There are two things that still irritate me a bit. On one hand, the scent has a slightly bitter, almost tar-like undertone that expands a bit in the background. As if it were subtly paying homage to the tobacco industry, which would be understandable in a way but not acceptable. However, this could be due to the fact that my flea market find is no longer the freshest, although spilled fragrances usually smell different.

In connection with this, I note that BIC Homme No 1, for its age, is quite usable in scent, aside from the slightly tar-like undertone. And so I wonder whether this is more an indication of natural or rather synthetic raw materials. After all, we are talking about Firmenich as the manufacturer/fragrance supplier. On the other hand, a high proportion of natural essences is promised according to the blister text. Could one actually believe that?

All in all, this is a relatively usable men’s perfume, which, however, is long outdated both in terms of zeitgeist and concept. The latter is not so far-fetched, and for those who needed a more or less acceptable scent quickly for a few marks, it was somewhat satisfactory.
Got a nice rendezvous or a spontaneous night out planned? Before you smell like a polecat, here’s the solution. And even afterwards, stowed away in your pants or handbag, it’s ready for use at any time! After all, 300 sprays were promised. That should last quite a while.

But even back then, there were pocket atomizers that looked more valuable and could be filled with the perfume of your first choice. It doesn’t have to be this makeshift solution from the supermarket or gas station. Moreover, as mentioned above, BIC's core competency lies elsewhere. Fans of the BIC lighter design may have perceived it differently, provided they were interested in fragrances.

Nevertheless, the saying holds: Cobbler, stick to your lasts. And BIC, stick to your pocket lighters!

Ginger Ale, many love it, but many do not, yet it is one of the most consumed non-alcoholic and slightly bitter soft drinks. It has a distinctive and refreshing scent that has been very well captured here.

The fragrance:
Wow, what a rendition. You immediately smell the typical and citrusy Ginger Ale scent, as if you had poured yourself a glass of this herbal lemonade.
But now comes the truly special something about this fragrance. You actually feel as if you could taste or inhale the sparkling bubbles of the carbonation in the drink. It almost makes your mouth water, so much so that you would like to drink the scent, which you probably shouldn’t do… even if it says Cologne on the label.

The longevity is terrible. At first, you enjoy the pleasant scent, and in the next moment, you wonder if you had merely imagined it. It lasts barely 30 minutes before it completely disappears.
The sillage is weak; it could be compared to 4711 Eau de Cologne fragrances. It is not meant to project the scent into the surroundings, but rather to refresh oneself temporarily.

The bottle is weak, as always. But it is sufficient, as always.
The label is weak, as before. It has a lot of stuff written on it, as usual.

This fragrance has been very authentically realized, and I also found it great that it could even convey that sparkling sensation.

Aside from that, it is one of the rarer Demeter fragrances that I actually find wearable, as it has a certain similarity to Eau de Cologne and similar citrusy refreshing scents. However, you can only enjoy it very briefly, as it unfortunately (oh no, I say unfortunately for a Demeter fragrance!) vanishes in the next moment. But I think it is a good alternative to 4711 if you want a quick freshness kick, although 4711 probably lasts more than twice as long.

So, feel free to test it. If you ever see it or get your hands on it…

Blub blubber blub…

This is powerful stuff.
Cumin and fresh, cut and dried tobacco u can smell pretty good.
I detect a little bit fruitiness also, a strange strawberry note, could be my nose.
Performance is great, stays long and has pretty powerful sillage.
This is quite potent and strong, not recommended for the younger crowd and for the Western nose it could be too much.
Overall quite unique smell and also some similarities to Rasasi Shuhrah as Mihaiu said, for me mainly the tobacco smell.

review_title: The Floral Bomb or: Throw Me a Bouquet!
review_content:
A big thank you to Sören for the sample of Lilanka EXTRAIT DE PARFUM :-) This is truly a striking "Flowerbomb." I actually like the scent, but as a man, it feels rather unsuitable for me. I find the fragrance to be very feminine, yet somehow also elegantly crafted (though not so elegant that I could justify the price of a bottle). The longevity is impressive at around 8 hours, and the sillage is also noteworthy.

I can't really dissect the top, heart, and base notes here, as it consistently smells brutally floral. Before I delve into the floral varieties I perceive, it's worth mentioning that it also has fresh, green, spicy, soapy, creamy, and slightly powdery nuances. In my view, the bouquet consists of lilac, freesias, roses, jasmine, a lot of hyacinths, lilies, lotus, lily of the valley, and a hint of tuberose.

This is indeed a well-crafted, fresh, and clean floral fragrance. But as I said, the price...

This is a very sweet pear, the kind you find in syrup rather than the crisp pear right off the tree. It's surrounded by honeydew melon, sweet florals, and vanilla in the base, so there's really nothing to balance or temper all this sweetness. Pink grapefruit is listed as a note, but my nose can't find a trace of it. Still, despite all the sweet notes this is a pretty fragrance, though not one I wear often. I like wearing it when I'm wearing lacy blouses and full ruffled skirts and other ultra feminine clothing. It's listed for wear by both men and women, but I think it would take a very confident sort of man to pull it off! Longevity and sillage are decent.

review_title: "I am Rich" is supposed to embody luxury and exclusivity. Well, somehow it doesn't for me...
review_content:
"I am Rich" - a simple bottle with a golden label.

“I am a brilliant tapestry. Richly woven of fine
golden thread. I am filled with blessings and
gratitude. Enduring happiness is mine.
I am rich.”

is written on the packaging.
A strange description, I think.
So I am supposed to feel "luxurious" while wearing this fragrance. Well, let's see.
It smells sweet at first. A lot of jasmine and gardenia rounded off by a gentle peach note. The opening is promising, but unfortunately, the perfume fades significantly. After a while, I perceive an artificial, slightly piercing note.
"I am Rich" is supposed to embody luxury and exclusivity. Well, somehow the goal has been missed here.
On one hand, the longevity is poor, and on the other hand, the fragrance notes blend into an artificial uniformity over time.

review_title: A PNW forest in spring, the flowers have just started blooming.
review_content: I wasn’t super excited by the opening of this, which I found to be just a sharp green note. But after letting it sit for a few minutes, it was a sweet aromatic woodland scent. I think the lavender, rosemary, and lemon blend wonderfully with the juniper wood. It did leave a slight yellow-green stain on the testing strip.

review_title: Robust green mossy blend with juniper and lavender
review_content:
Pineward Perfumes Juniperus is a very recent release from this Colorado/Utah-based house, a bold green mossy woody sharp blend featuring juniper, lavender, rosemary, patchouli, and sandalwood. It has a vaguely savory background with the rosemary but mainly a bold center of that smells like rich spring outdoor experience in the woods, full of plants and life and a mossy greenness that seems to come from the juniper and lavender, a little sharp but not too sharp, and not really floral despite what I figure to be a good use of lavender. It feels like a relatively full masculine-leaning fresh cologne, perhaps something that might’ve appeared in the last 25 years in a designer lab but with a little more grace and authenticity. A very interesting release that I’m nonetheless unsure I would wear a lot. Overall, though, I like it very much.

Juniperus is EDT concentration and is priced at $135/80/50 for 57/37/17ml and performs quite well, so it’s a great value, perhaps better so than the line’s higher-concentration options at higher price points.

7 out of 10

... commented and rated you a year ago, you would have received full marks and a tailored hymn of praise. I would have appreciated your floral freshness, the slightly green notes, the subtle raspberry fruitiness, and the light woody finish. Well, if I had done that, you would have come off better.
But I didn't.
And now I will be ruthlessly honest with you.
You annoy me.
Your floral freshness smells artificial. You're chewing noisily on a raspberry Hubba Bubba, so also artificial raspberry, no subtle fruitiness, but a full-on smack right in the face. Ouch.
Your finish... Well. Just get on with it already. Thanks.

Overall: Met you while tipsy in the night, thought you were great, and took you home. The next morning, I was horrified to realize that I had drunk something pretty, and now in a rush and panic, trying to get rid of the souvenir.

So, when I'm drunk, it goes... ;)

review_title: Fly with Raspberry Flavor - or Skin Chemistry Part Two
review_content:
Do you know Flit? It used to be very well-known and widely used, even though it really smelled terrible. Flit came from the Flit spray (unfortunately, I don't have a photo at hand) and reliably sent even the toughest six to eight-legged critters to the great beyond in no time. As far as I know, it wasn't particularly health-promoting for humans either.

Today in the perfumery, the bottle of Addict Shine caught my eye: clear lines and a color that promised a light elegance combined with freshness. The first test on paper cards confirmed: oh, nice, fresh - I'll give this a try. So I generously sprayed the "addictive substance" on the back of my hand. Indeed, the opening was as expected fresh-fruity-floral. Unexpectedly, however, something sharp almost burned my nasal mucous membranes, and that was definitely not the alcohol. Shortly thereafter, caramelized, sticky artificial raspberries covered the back of my hand. And to top it all off, a hefty dose of Flit with raspberry aroma (apparently a modernized version à la Impulse deodorant) followed, which proved to be extremely persistent.
