The opening smells a little vintage-like and alcoholic for the very first moment, but it's not impossible that this is due to the age of my sample.
Then the scent turns sweeter quickly. In the drydown it even becomes a little powdery, with lots of vanilla and white musk as a base.

At this point, when most of the grapefruit has burned off, it really smells like I imagine a opening a glass bowl full of creamy caramel candies and pink bubblegum would smell like, with a little clean powder on top of that.

So far, the few other fragrances I tried from 4160 all felt kind of homemade, typically indie to me. This one smells a little smoother and more "professionally made" (for the lack of a better word). Not like a designer scent, but closer to that. To me, that's an advantage, to some others it might be the opposite.

All in all this didn't blow my mind, but it's a very cute and enjoyable perfume if you like gourmands with rose. I like how it's both playful and cozy.

I very much like this fragrance, it’s so easy to wear. The pink grapefruit lends it a freshness and is blended beautifully with the rose, cotton candy and musk. I’ts not too sweet and i like that and it smells different.Longevity is about 2 to 3 hours on me but well worth a respray.

This morning, a package arrived from a lovely perfumer with many exciting samples and decants of fragrances that I had on my wishlist or had never heard of before. This includes the brand Stendhal and this perfume.
From the very first scent molecules that reached my nose, I was immediately captivated. From that moment on, I couldn't get enough of this dreamily beautiful fragrance.
I feel like a fairy gliding through a sea of delicately scented flowers, first the cherry blossoms, then the rose, mixed with heliotrope, beneath me a river of vanilla and musk.
I find this fragrance to be very feminine, sensual, sexy, and breathtakingly beautiful. Due to the vanilla and musk, it exudes a cozy warmth and comfort. Perfect for this time of year when the weather outside is cold and dreary, and perhaps a fire is burning in the fireplace while you cuddle together on the sofa, simply enjoying each other's company and experiencing a wonderful moment of happiness.
The longevity is enormous, and I am grateful to have the opportunity to test this fantastic fragrance, and I have already added it to my wishlist.

After being completely enchanted by "Ambre Sublime" from Stendhal, which has of course long since found a place in my collection, I was curious to see what else Stendhal has to offer.

So here we have "Elixir Blanc". The opening is relatively fresh, with the delicious cherry blossom and angelica primarily filling my nose. The pink pepper tickles a bit, but it doesn't disturb.
Slowly, Madame Rose and iris join in. The rose is a very refined lady, somewhat reserved, yet still present. The iris quickly gives the fragrance a pleasantly powdery touch, which it retains even after hours.
Then the base notes spread out quickly, primarily sandalwood, vanilla, and musk. However, they do not overpower the rose; rather, they lay beneath it to support its noble scent.
I only notice the cedar at the very end, but its woodiness is not as pronounced as in some other fragrances.
What remains? A super elegant mix of rose, vanilla, musk, and woods. I know that perfumes cannot be "delicious," but I can't think of a better adjective for this one.

All in all, I find this more than balanced fragrance to be very elegant and feminine.
It is cozy, subtly sexy, clean, not sweet, rather close to the skin and unobtrusive.
In terms of quality, I would classify it as top-tier; its longevity is astonishing (the few drops from last night I could still faintly smell this morning after waking up), and I perceive the bottle as a true reflection of the fragrance: exclusivity inside and out.

Since the white elixir is a bit too feminine for me, I will (admittedly with a heavy heart) not use it for myself.

So I will have 10ml left over ;-))

review_title: I hardly dare to say it
review_content: ....aaaaaber So lost in you clearly appeals to me more than Musk Therrapy....and why? It’s not so piercing..it’s blackcurrant/creamy mandarin. The fruity clean girl scent! Not soapy, no lavender or pepper. Fruity, creamy, just clean. In the opening, the juicy blackcurrant, mandarin falls into musk cream, bam, this is where I like it best. Those who compare too much with Musk Therrapy or expect something along those lines will find the opening too sweet. Please be patient for a few minutes. If Mont Blanc Signature is too scratchy, Musk Therrapy too expensive, and S.oliver, I think White Seduction too weak and bland, then this candidate is worth testing. By the way, no biting lily of the valley. For me, the sweet mandarin is the note that dominates the most. I’m already looking forward to when my bottle arrives. In my olfactory world, wearable all year round.

This is a funny one because I am a huuuge fan of AEOOJ, and there are some similarities, but where I find AEOOJ "dry," this one is "wet." Where AEOOJ conjures a sun baked open road, this has a musty-ness, like an overgrown barn. It's largely pleasurable, but there is one note that turns me off. I am not sure what it is. Maybe Civet? idk.

I'm not one for writing reviews but my experience with Caji seems quite different to others so I thought I'd share. It may be my skin, or my nose struggling with top notes or my inexperience, but I did not perceive this as a "fresh green" foin coupe at all. I didn't even realize it was supposed to have a cucumber note since I had read a summary of the description that only mentions the hay, jasmine, orris, and civet.

When I sprayed this, I certainly smelled hay- but not green nor fresh. I seem to have skipped most of the top notes and didn't get jasmine or cucumber. I smelled hay, and ANIMALS. Then vanilla came through gently over time. I honestly enjoyed it and it was very familiar and comforting to me, but I couldn't put my finger on it.

After some thoughts, I've concluded that it smells akin to the rodent section at a pet store (but don't turn your nose up at this!). Like a room full of bunnies and their feed, or picking up and sniffing your beloved pet ferret or rat. Dried hay-like, warm, and sweet, but just also a bit ammonia-like and dirty. But in a good way (to me). I think the civet is front-and-center for me, unlike it seems to be with other reviewers.

I really enjoy it, but the way it smells on me might not be the most pleasing to others, so I'm unsure when I would wear it. Will be returning to it with a fresher nose to attempt to find those top notes eventually.

review_title: Expansive, gentle hay on a cloudy afternoon
review_content:
When I saw that Chris Rusak was releasing a foin coupe I got so hyped. I love grass/hay scents. After the notes and description were released I was nervous - so much jasmine and civet, notes that I'm typically _very_ wary of. I shouldn't have doubted. It's great.

It opens with an expansive green, wet, fresh-cut lawn scent with a vague rooty undertone that leans suede/rubber or wax (orris?). My initial notes described it as "grass stains on new white sneakers". My nose is not particularly adroit, so I don't really get the cucumber or violet leaf in the published description, but i suspect the cucumber is what lends the vague watery accord. It's incredibly reminiscent to me of sitting on this athletic field of artificial turf during and after the lockdowns in summer of 2020. It's gentle, relaxed, unhurried - not things I associate with the pandemic itself but with the brief respite given by sprawling on the grass in the sun outside in the late spring with all the fear and chaos a safe distance away.

As it settles, the grass starts to dry out - the suede/rubber becomes a little more noticeable and the more watery accords of the top notes fade, transforming the fresh mown lawn grass into something much more hay-like and wildflower. It stays airy and expansive, with soft green powdery pollen and the waxy/rubbery note wavering on the edge of some kind of heady solvent, like fuel for a mower or oiled tools in a shed.

In the drydown, it becomes reminiscent of the base of AEOOJ. The rubbery/suede/waxy note fully transforms from rooty to solvent, mixing with a difficult-to-pinpoint musk. It lays close and light on my skin as a musky heady-aromatic floral, with the barest touch of hay. I don't notice the vanilla from the published description, and the "extreme dose" of civet stays very soft and subtle (at least to my nose). But perhaps I'm anosmic at this point?

After another hour or two later the airy rubbery accord disappears and in its place the musky suede is all that (barely) remains. It's animalic in a warm-fur-and-skin way, kinda like huffing the scruff of my cat or my friend's ferret. Fuzzy, comforting and pleasant.

Projection is good. It's no nostril-blasting nuke, but it develops an effective bubble. Longevity is low-moderate - it's down to a subtle skin scent after about 4-5 hours.

The PR copy says "Caji is a contemplative perfume, the sort of pleasure perfect for a day of inclement weather spent indoors, relaxing in comfort.". Today's a rainy, unseasonably warm day for December and I agree it suits the mood well. It's a gentle scent, overcast without being lugubrious. Also: my neighbor's cat loves it too! Must be the civet.

Another green that I can wear without it turning into a sour sweat smell on my acidic skin.. I normally stay away from green but this is a melon green, not a leaf or grass green..

I mainly get an aquatic melon with lily of valley, ylang ylang and jasmine.. the peach, rose, and sandalwood lay quietly in the background. I get a hint of the rhubarb but I'm not finding spices or vetivier in it.

Sillage is very good and it lasts over 6 hrs which is also very good on me.

I personally do not care that much for the bottles especially since this diamond line all look basically the same.. I painted a strip of nail polish around the 'studded' section in order to tell them apart faster, too bad they didnt put a couple red/green/blue rhinestones there in the first place

D&S wears great on paper, not on me. The mix of florals (jasmine, lov, freesia) is headache & asthma inducing. It's very strong for an EDT, even with a light hand. I like it but can only wear it on clothing or scarves. It's a contemporary bottle that looks as pictured.

I've since tested Boucheron Jaipur & Boucheron Jaipur Saphir. To me, ET Diamonds & Sapphires is similar in scent, but not quality, to these 2 Boucherons.

UPDATE: I've acquired a small vintage bottle in EDP formulation, in a solid gold canister with simulated diamonds. What a difference this makes! The vintage version a much more wearable and better quality. It's just enough to change my rating from neutral-minus to neutral-plus.

White Diamonds and Black Pearls are also ET fragrances that are better in vintage.

I saw an interview once with Mrs Taylor in which she explains why she wanted to make perfumes. Apparently, all the perfumes she tried she didn't like, plus a lot of perfumes smelled alike to her and she ended up layering several perfumes to get one scent she would like. Somewhat recognizing this complaint, this story sounded interesting to me. So much so, that when I saw "Diamonds & Rubies" and "Diamonds & Sapphires" for a bargain price I decided to take the risk and -blindly- purchased both.
Well, The bottles are very pretty, they remind me of her jewelry penchant (I think that is the point).
I sniffed "Diamonds & Rubies" and can say: it's a pleasant and warm oriental that I shall be wearing one day; I just haven't found the right mood for it yet.
"Diamonds & Sapphires" is another story, I sniffed it and almost got a headache! Lily of the valley, that is ALL I smell! And not in a small amount either! I guess it's a perfume that one only uses one spray of or walk through the mist after spraying it in the room. Any other form of applying is -for me- too much lily. I have it stored and am undecided about it. But just the other day I saw "Diamonds & Emeralds" for a bargain price (all these are 100ML!) Shall I succumb and purchase? For these bargain priced perfumes they never offer a tester. Hmmm

Darling Elizabeth, I am not afraid of Virginia Woolf, but your Lily is scary! x.x.x

It’s become a bit of a quest for me as I have grown really curious about old perfumes that were created long ago. So I bought this one from this great actress, and what I liked the most is the bottle :) The perfume itself is quite nice but very-very flowery and, to my taste, a bit suffocating. Definitely a granny’s perfume, sorry :))

I want to start by saying that this fragrance is not sweet at all and that fans of sweet floral or candy scents will not find what they are looking for. While there are plenty of floral accords, they come from candidates that are not particularly sweet in nature. Diamonds and Sapphires is not even powdery or just with a hint.

A sparkling, cool, faceted beauty from the house of Taylor (or rather, Arden).

The opening has a slight prick in the nose, and I am glad that the lily of the valley does not dominate, although it is clearly perceptible. Freesia is also not the sweetest of flowers. This is fully intentional and immediately conveys the purpose of this perfume. Beautiful, cool (but NOT cold) and willful.

Throughout, there are occasional similarities to White Diamonds, but this one is brighter and more radiant. Diamonds and Sapphires is a bit darker, but no less intense. The rhubarb (also a funny ingredient) really ensures that a small biting acidity remains. But I think it is meant to keep this willful note intact.

The base becomes a bit softer, with no trace of vanilla coziness.

A completely "non-cozy" fragrance, beautiful, but creaky and somewhat rough. Not suitable for winter.

was a film with the wonderful Liz Taylor and my first thought when spraying Diamonds and Sapphires was of it. You could hardly describe this fragrance better, as it is unruly and brittle. At least at first impression. The greeting is cool and distant, but not unfriendly or even arrogant. There are no hugs or "kisses" when getting to know each other. D&S has class and does...

I am surprised that there are not more reviews and statements about this "May scent." After all, it radiates a lot of freshness and floral beauty, making it a joy to sniff.
Everything wintry falls away, allowing the sometimes quite cool, sometimes quite warm spring air to flow freely. And all of this is wrapped in much green and bright blossoms. Nothing sticky-sweet emanates from it. Nothing oppressively heavy.
And yet it is substantial! Brimming with bitter lily of the valley, delicate freesia, a bit of rose, and... probably also quite a bit of galbanum, which brings in that slightly bitter-spicy note. The green of fresh leaves, the green of a bright birch grove.
And a slightly green woodiness that forms the solid base of the fragrance. No fuss with a lot of frills, just bright and clear. And with a certain "knowing" elegance that only a few fragrances possess. These diamonds and sapphires radiate clarity. And their "setting" is made of simple silver. The "ornaments" are formed by the fragrance itself. It doesn’t need much "fuss" around it. Because it is already such a one in green and bitter-floral!

One thing first: I only have a miniature of this fragrance, but in the Extrait concentration. It may be that the current EDT is different or at least weaker. Also regarding reformulation, my comment refers to the original version. My copy, purchased in the mid-90s, has a distinctly orange tint, but is olfactorily intact.

This fragrance feels very opulent and intense on me. A few drops are enough. It is floral-heavy, yet simultaneously radiates a cool elegance. In this regard, it is somewhat similar to "Eternity," which I like less than D&S. I envision a dark-haired woman in an elegant blue evening gown, adorned with a sparkling silver rhinestone necklace (after all, hardly anyone can afford real gems with diamonds and sapphires in noticeable sizes...). Yes, it would have suited the beautiful Liz! Although she probably wore different perfumes during her lifetime than those marketed under her name. She also had the matching (real) jewelry in her legendary collection...

I like to bring out the small bottle on a spring evening, even if there is no occasion for an evening gown.

Diamonds and Sapphires surprises me, as it is bright and full at the same time.
Lush bouquets of flowers waft around my nose, with a pleasant greenish undertone.
The stems are included here.

On my skin, it develops slightly soapy and sweet, without losing its brightness.
Could it be the freesia and jasmine that make it shine?
In any case, the gemstone theme is well executed.
Musk makes it sparkle again, and sandalwood makes it beautifully cuddly.

A floral, elegant evening scent with a touch of luxury.

The bottle already exudes timeless elegance. The scent matches the exterior perfectly. At first very zesty green, the character transforms into a cool elegance of spring flowers. It carries a hint of herbaceous notes, yet still feels very feminine. Not a sillage monster, but lasting. For me, a perfect "go-to" fragrance.

review_title: A really beautiful, floral, and clean fresh scent
review_content: I really liked my bottle of Diamonds and Sapphires EAU DE TOILETTE right from the start, even though I find my vintage miniatures of Diamonds and Sapphires PARFUM even more beautiful and fruity. Curiously, the longevity on my skin is better here. The scent lasts more than 10 hours with a solid sillage. The top note smells very...

review_title: Reformulated to Death or Skin Chemistry?
review_content:
I expected a rather strong floral scent with great longevity and noticeable sillage. Unfortunately, I only got a faint breeze.
A light floral fragrance, quite nice at first. I would have rated the scent much better afterwards. But the longevity! After 2 hours, there was hardly anything left to smell, and after 3 hours, it was all gone.
I don't know if it's simply due to my skin chemistry. Or if the fragrance has been - like so many others - reformulated to death.

This is my first comment. I'm just going to write freely.

The perfume from BB About Men is the first one I used because it was a gift for my 16th birthday.

The scent of BB is not intrusive, but still subtle. For my age back then, it was actually just right. The fragrance is very fresh and spicy. The fruity top note and the heart note are in a very refreshing combination with each other.

Unlike with big fragrances like Terre d'Hermès, for example, from my ex "Ew, you stink!", the reactions to this perfume have always been positive.
Today, I like to wear About Men in my simple everyday life, like at work. However, I find the longevity quite short, as I can no longer perceive the scent on my skin after a good 5 hours.

For the price, I think there is nothing to complain about with this perfume. :) Therefore, I recommend it especially for young beginners or for simple everyday use.

I wanted to test some perfumes at Mallach, but the saleswoman seemed to be on an extended lunch break, so an alternative had to be found... off to DM and tested some "cheap perfumes"... why not...
With all my might, I tried to push aside the price, the brand, and the environment, focusing solely on the scent qualities... but unfortunately, I have to say that you always have in the back of your mind that the fragrances there don't carry the big names... how easily influenced I (and certainly most others) am :-(

Bruno Banani About Men was the second perfume I tested on my skin there... first impression: strong, unique, extremely sweet, fruity... what is this? Pear, banana, or apple? After a few minutes, I settled on the latter, and it smells like this for a long time... a chic, noble, oriental, fresh, intense, interesting apple...
After a few minutes, I realized that I knew this scent from somewhere... I went through in my head which big name could be a scent twin? But no, I couldn't think of anyone, and then I remembered where I knew the scent from: I must have worn it before, yes, even owned it!
I started collecting perfumes half a year ago, before that I wore One Million, before that Cool Water, and before that... I think just Axe or something^^ I was still a teenager/child, but I must have received this scent as a gift from my mother during my youth, otherwise, this scent memory cannot be explained^^ I absolutely could not remember the inconspicuous, more than boring bottle (rightly so!).

The scent, however, is far better than the bottle, but due to its sweetness and uniqueness, it is difficult to categorize and wear... my poor classmates in middle school, when I wore this every day back then, that must have been a bit much^^
The sillage was really good for me yesterday, but maybe only because I concentrated so intensely on the smell... longevity also top. At a level where you wish for every scent (8 hours!).
In the drydown, it develops away from the sweet apple towards the beautiful tonka bean.

All in all, a good scent from BB, I think maybe even the best... clear line, not such a mishmash like many other BB scents! Still, my nose (+ my brain) has simply gotten used to other scent levels...
+10 nostalgia % ;-)

My boyfriend uses it and I really like it.

It smells masculine without being too strong or overpowering. Strangely, I mostly smell the floral heart note very strongly in About Men. Nevertheless, I can confidently recommend this fragrance to any man.

In my opinion, the sillage is also longer-lasting than most men perceive. I can still smell it on my favorite wearer hours later ;)

Of all my "nice" drugstore perfumes that I owned during school, only two are still available for purchase, namely Mexx Man (Meh!) and this one - now also off the market, but still obtainable. Out of sheer nostalgia, I decided to go for it - and I didn’t let the endearing product name "Toilet Water" on the re-import deter me. And since I can't help but share my two cents, here’s an obituary:

"We have gathered here to bid farewell to you, our brother Bruno. Born as the son of a lingerie manufacturer and a chemistry lab technician, you grew up in modest circumstances. In your childhood, you were truly sweet; people who knew you described round, red paradise apple cheeks.

You never sought the big stage, always remaining humble, inconspicuous, calm, and friendly. Yet your closest friends always appreciated you! You were the coolest member of the chess club and the uncoolest member of the prom committee. Far too soon, you leave us now. Ashes to ashes, tonka bean to tonka bean!”

In plain terms: I used to really like this scent, but now I’m somewhat disappointed due to its really poor performance on me - you have to spray a lot to get anything out of it, and you can repeat the process after 3 hours! I also don’t think it’s due to an old bottle.

The scent itself may be strongly synthetic and too simple for the local, niche-fragrance-spoiled audience - in its ecological niche of youth fragrances, it can certainly be positively mentioned - absolutely not an overt shower gel freshie, and just as little an overly sweet calorie bomb, a scent that shouldn’t really offend anyone and that I honestly don’t find difficult to wear, yet it still has something quite unique. At the start, a very sweet apple, later a mild-spicy clean man scent with dominant tonka bean. From the heart note with the indicated flowers, I hardly perceive anything.

The bottle inevitably makes me think of the Titanic... even though in the 30ml version there is at least no risk of tipping over, it’s just not beautiful. Nevertheless, it can happily remain as a guilty pleasure at the back of the shelf.

About Men is for me a perfect men's fragrance if you don't want to spend a lot of money on a rather heavy but truly great scent.

What I appreciate about this perfume is its good spiciness and the oriental note.
Since I believe this scent is the most expressive Banani fragrance, it is also my absolute favorite from Bruno Banani.

Above all, it doesn't smell cheap... but simply very masculine and expressive.

I would buy it again and again.
Just don't wear it in the summer, as it could be really overwhelming.

Together with "Pure Man," my favorite from BB. I gifted BB Man, I couldn't stand the scent anymore (although it's by no means a bad fragrance!). This one is oriental without being too heavy, with fresh notes added. Actually my everyday scent when I don't want to stand out too much. For the price (you can get it for 11.- euros), you really can't go wrong. Doesn't smell...

Hello everyone, this will be my first fragrance comment and I hope I do it right. This scent has truly captivated me and I use it very often, alongside BB Pure Man. It starts off fresh, sweet, oriental, aquatic with a slight spicy scent. A little later, it transitions for me into a fresh, oriental, woody and a spicy-sweet note. It feels very subtle and is not overpowering;...

I use this perfume sometimes because I also like to wear men's fragrances. But you shouldn't use this scent too often, as it can quickly become boring and start to feel unpleasant. That's just my opinion. So for going out or special occasions, it's definitely a great fragrance, but it's less suitable for everyday wear.

Best regards

...since About Men EAU DE TOILETTE was a really trendy fragrance. It felt like everyone from the younger generation was wearing it. Marketing and advertising certainly played a big role, and that's how the scent ended up with me.

I really liked the fruity top note. There were green apples and citrus fruits. The heart note was floral but also a bit honey-like. In the base, there were woody hints and tonka beans. In the background, there was also a touch of vanilla.

The longevity wasn't great, not to mention the sillage.

I fell in love again today ... with yet another of the many faces that the beautiful Rose presents. Having been after trying this fragrance for the longest time I finally made the hour long drive to my nearest niche outlet and this 'Rosebud' has captivated and enchanted me.

Adding to the pleasure, this fragrance was on seasonal markdown so I immediately bought one of the three left in the store. This appears to have been a fatal mistake ... I should have bought the lot, an oversight I intend on correcting as soon as possible.
Bouton de Rose opens with a tart blast of Cranberry, quickly followed by a delectable surge of green ... definitely the Papyrus. What follows is the beautiful intensity of a naturally grown rosebud about to burst into flower, still clinging to it's green bits but with the promise of heavenly sweetness, cleverly provided in this blend by the addition of Freesia and Peony. There are subtle hints of white florals too in the smallest amounts of Jasmine and Tuberose, as if adding their soft whispers to this budding voice from another corner of the garden ... paying homage to the Queen about to be born.
The dry down of Bouton de Rose is simply wonderful ... the woody earthiness of Frankincense and the resinoid Amber softly recalling sap and freshly turned, damp soil with a fungal, mushroomy touch.
I've seen on other fora that this fragrance is classified as a feminine. I beg to differ ... with Roses for men like "Declaration d'Un Soir", "Twill Rose" and "Rosissimo" on the market, there is no reason that Bouton de Rose cannot be worn successfully by either gender.

This creation by Le Prince Jardinier has skyrocketed to a place in my top 5 all time favorite Rose fragrances. It will definitely be a staple in my rotation.

Bouton de Rose - the rosebud - is an interesting rose scent. Yes, you should like rose fragrances to wear it, and yes, it can definitely be worn by the male faction as well.

Bouton de Rose does not correspond to what I would have expected from the garden prince. It is actually just a bud and a bright rose at that. Pink, white, or very delicate light yellow. The scent starts fruity-fresh and it takes a little while for the flowers to develop.

The rosebud does not smell alone; many delicate little flowers surround it and give it volume. I feel transported to an English rose garden, where the roses have not yet fully bloomed, but they are already showing their colorful buds and conveying their delicate scent.

Initially quite sweet, the sweetness gradually diminishes and the scent becomes clearer and finer. Up to the base, Bouton de Rose is extremely subtle and close to the skin. Longevity is so-so, it could be better. For the original retail price, I would not buy the scent, as the longevity is too poor. However, since I got it very cheaply on the bay, I will gladly use it and probably finish it faster than my other rose fragrances.

The LPJ EdTs are no longer available on the LPJ website and are sold out at most perfumeries. So it could be that they might disappear from the market in the foreseeable future. Where available, the prices are significantly reduced, making a purchase definitely worthwhile.

I have to admit, I was really curious about this scent.
I like fresh scents anyway, and with mint, I was excited.
Now I'm just recovering from the remnants of my cold, yet I could smell enough to clearly say that this scent is a real stinker for me.
I feel like I'm being suffocated by the rose scent.
I don't find it fresh at all; I smell something sharp and this dominant rose fragrance.
I washed it off right away, which says it all.

review_title: Tea and Rhubarb in the Rose Garden
review_content:
I initially thought Diamond Sparkle was a sweet rose scent after the sniff & scratch test on the cellophane packaging and decided to take it with me. There were no testers available.
Unfortunately.
Because what I smelled after spraying it was more robust tea and sour notes of rhubarb and tart citrus fruits than rose, and certainly not sweet rose.
The development was ultimately reconciliatory, as over time the rose comes to the forefront, and the scent becomes sweeter as well. However, it is a type of sweetness that I perceive as rather crystalline and angular, not a soft, gentle sweetness. When I was little, I enjoyed dipping raw, peeled rhubarb stalks in crystal sugar and eating them, and this scent reminds me of that. Intense acidity meets intense sweetness, and it crunches and crackles wonderfully.
But even this angular sweetness becomes a bit softer over time, and the acidity noticeably diminishes. Then the tireless strong tea and the roses dominate.
In the dry down, slightly woody notes make themselves known, and the overall impression becomes softer and rounder.
This scent is not very long-lasting; after five or six hours, I have to get very close to my wrist with my nose to smell anything.

I recently snagged a bottle for about 9.00 EUR at REWE in the Tchibo corner. Actually, I didn't like it that much when it came out last year, but now there was no tester, and for the price, I didn't want to leave it behind.

At first, it's very intense. I usually like strong scents, but this one is already heavily overdone with just two sprays, at least when it's over 20 degrees. I keep smelling something like roses with berries and pepper rising from my wrists. Even now, here at the computer, and after more than 6 hours, the scent is still wafting up to my nose. It has also clung to the sleeves of my jacket; hopefully, that will fade...

Unfortunately, it doesn't remind me of Nivea at all, unlike Lissy, and it doesn't come off as powdery to me either. See the title, I don't want to say much more about it. The only other thing that comes to mind in this context is mothballs.

Really a shame, maybe it just doesn't handle the heat well?

edit: I actually find it really good now, a wonderful, unusual rose scent!

review_title: One of the Most Beautiful Scents My Nose Has Ever Smelled
review_content:
I have rarely found such a good fragrance as this one.
This scent is cool and zesty, but it transforms in a few seconds
into a perfect niveous note and envelops with a gentle powderiness.

Fragrance where have you been! A limited special edition???
This is a masterpiece in liquid form.
And another edition is urgently requested.!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

PSSSSST: Attention folks, 4711 Wunderwasser Women has sneaked up on Sparkle.

Oui opens with some bright and sugary fruit, lots of citrus, but the pineapple is fairly easy to spot too. It's very, very uplifting. Fresh fragrances are either a relief in hot weather, or they're a transporting relief in cooler months. Either way, this is no exception.

It settles into a shampoo-y and floral scent, familiar and summery. Orange blossom goes white well with citrus IMO, but this isn't noticeably *orange blossom*...it's just a malange of white florals.

It's aquatic, it feels quenching and wet. I kept thinking of how I would wear this to the pool as I smelled it today. It's a weird thing to say, but I love swimming, and I've often thought of what works or doesn't at the pool, and this is absolutely something that would. I'd bet on it.

"Splash" is a great title for this, and the blocky bright blues even remind me of pool toys/inflatables!

review_title: Meant to be paired with Wild Sand
review_content:
This scent was released as a pair with Wild Sand in 2023. They are intended to be layered to create a unique scent. I'm not into florals, so I don't love this one as much as Wild Sand. If layering the two together, you will need to spray LOTS of Wild Sand and just a spritz or two of Endless Sea. Endless Sea is much stronger and overpowering.

Last year I bought the hand soap, and it's a shame the spray didn't smell closer to that. I LOVED the smell of the hand soap! It was fresh and clean.

I love this fragrance! I can't believe I got multiple samples of it on my last visit to the Diptyque counter several months ago and have never tried it until today. I was busy trying to convince myself that somewhere within Diptyque's Volutes, L'eau Tarocco and L'eau de Lente, lay my new Summer signature scent. I love the low-moderate sillage as well as the transparent quality of Diptyque creations and I also love the dichotomy of surprisingly good longevity with this line, at least on my skin. L'eau de L'eau starts off very citrusy and fresh on the top notes with a sunny lemon note with a pinch of dry cinnamon powder. I don't really smell any grapefruit or petitgrain, but perhaps I am blocking these out since they are not my favorite notes. For the first five minutes my reaction was "Meh, that is just o.k." and then suddenly it was as if someone wearing a beautiful orange blossom, lavender and geranium scent walked in, lit a clove cigarette and ordered a chilled candied ginger martini with mandarin zest peel curled over the side. Then I realized it was, in fact, L'eau de L'eau. This scent definitely changes and expands over time. The top was fresh, almost professional, brisk and urban. The middle is clove-a-licious, dark and spicy almost Goth and the base is a mello, soft and calming Tonka and Benzoin. I don't detect the patchouli here, but that is a good thing, IMO. It all mélanges together culminating in a Your-skin-but-spicy-scent. This is masterfully blended and would make an ideal signature scent for a man or woman. I would wear this primarily for daytime- it's very close to the skin after the first hour, but seems to be lasting a good 6 hours. I'm almost sorry I got into this sample because now definitely need a full bottle ASAP!

L’Eau de L’Eau… so if I understand correctly, the scent is now water from water or water out of water or something like that? How does one come up with such a name?

This could have been thought up directly by Aquaman himself… and I, being a nerd, am already mentioning a comic book character again… oh no, oh dear! … and to top it off, a rather unpopular character (I quote Raj from The Big Bang Theory: “Shitty Aquaman!”).

Be that as it may, since Philosykos I have been testing Diptyque fragrances from time to time, but I have hardly found a scent that I liked as much as the mentioned fig scent. I even found some quite dreadful (e.g., Olène), but as they say, one does not give up (unless you don’t want to read any more comments from me, then I’ll quickly and sadly disappear from here *sniffle*).

Well then, let’s get to the scent…

The scent:
At the beginning, you can definitely smell a grapefruit, which also smells nice, but for a scent that one might think is fresh because of the name, it is quite spicy. Because right after application, you can perceive a very intense cinnamon and clove note, with the clove being so strong that it can almost overwhelm you if overapplied.
A little later, the scent has a slightly classic touch in the background, which might be due to the notes of lemon and lavender. The cinnamon fades a bit, and the clove also becomes calmer.
Along with the roses, slightly floral notes come in, lightening up the scent a little.
The fruity notes from the base remind more of oranges and fit well with the other scents.
A bit later, you can detect a slightly soapy-synthetic component, which you have to smell for specifically, and the impression is almost lost through the somewhat sharp clove, which is still well detectable in the base, while the slightly sweet cinnamon remains in the background.

The sillage and longevity:
The projection is strong, the scent will definitely be noticed by others, and that for a somewhat longer period of time. If sprayed on generously, a scent cloud will surely remain!
The longevity is quite good at about eight hours!

The bottle:
The bottle is tall and more rectangular than the somewhat rounder bottles usually known from Diptyque. It is clear and has a transparent label with a frame on the front. Besides the name, there is a drawing of a rocky stream and trees.
The cap is black and cylindrical. Everything is nicely done, although it might have looked better if the label had a white background.

Okay, I am glad to be able to write here that L’Eau de L’Eau has turned out to be quite a nice scent (and not yet another Diptyque flop for me). The scent gives off a rather autumnal atmosphere for me, as it comes across warm and is not as fresh as the name L’Eau might suggest.

As a daytime scent for the somewhat not-so-warm summer days or early autumn as well as in spring, it is quite usable. Additionally, it is more of a daytime or casual scent than one meant for going out.

I wonder how Aquaman sprays himself with a scent underwater? No,… I’ll stop with the comics, you probably don’t want to know anything about that anyway (whyyyy...??).

Yes, the scent is finally a Diptyque fragrance worth checking out, as long as you don’t have an aversion to a strong clove scent!

This scent is strangely good! You definitely have to like the combination of cinnamon, fruit, and clove. I really enjoy what I'm smelling.

My first impression after spraying: mulled wine in a fresh-fruity summer version. Although the cinnamon and clove are noticeable from the very beginning, this fragrance is not heavy at all.

Even with the heart note, the scent remains pleasant and does not drift into a wintry territory. The ginger gives the heart a nice light spiciness.

It then transitions into the base with a spicy-fresh character. This becomes a bit sweeter, while the cinnamon note fades. Patchouli and tonka bean are well balanced. Despite the oriental note, it lacks the typical heaviness often found in orientals.

As a fan of oriental perfumes, I say in this case: thumbs up for L´Eau de L´Eau!

Whoopie! Cinnamon is in charge here. All phobics, hands off, please.
What’s amazing is that even in the top note, a strong cinnamon note stands out. It seems to detach itself from the back of the hand and waft around in the air. You can’t ignore it at all. Occasionally, a few fresh, slightly prickly tones peek out cautiously from under the spice cloud, but they don’t really dare to come out.
This scent is for spice lovers. After the spectacular cinnamon appearance, the clove slowly joins in, running protectively in front of the ginger. This doesn’t weaken the intense onslaught (somehow the blend reminds me of rice pudding with sugar and cinnamon, warm, cinnamon freshly sprinkled), but it does become calmer now.
Where can you wear this scent? Naturally, everywhere. I would be a bit cautious with it in the office.

Roses wrapped with musk. I wish I could get more from this perfume, but after wearing it twice, sadly I cannot. There are other notes that did draw me to it, but I'm disappointed that Trellis is basically pure roses on me. If you truly enjoy roses, then this is one for you. I do believe there are other offerings on the market that could be better for that type of floral offering. Pretty, but too linear and not as full-bodied as I expected. Very soft and sits close to the skin.

Sandara makes me feel like a little fairy floating around the redwoods. The fragrance smells woody and a little damp and makes me think of ferns and forest streams. I get violets, which creates that cool water feeling. It's not necessarily one of my very favorites, but I like it well enough to wear it on occasion. I find it lasts, and sillage is on the quieter side, which I like anyway.

I'm going to write about this perfume as I could write about a beloved person I've lost. In fact, this fragrance was the mate of my 20years and it represents the springtime of my life.
I discovered it and tested the first time in a drugstore in Brescia, Northern Italy, where I studied at the university.
It was love at first smell: so flowery-fruity, so soft, so perfect for my Young age!
I cannot forget the gorgeous rasperry top notes characterizing this scent as rich as a secret garden . Then, I remember the warmer and very feminin flowery bouquet revealing all its innocent sensuality.
At the base, the unforgettable sweet vanilla notes lasting on my skin for hours without resulting too intoxicating or sweetish. The sillage was good and the result so ethereal and so perfect for a "jeune fille en fleur"!
It was a little corner of Paradise, contained in a very romantic and refined bottle which was a little masterpiece to show on the bathroom perfumes shelf.
A scent connected to the springtime , to the first ray of light of the day, to a bon ton and flowery dress , to pastel nuances.
This paradise is lost not only because the oerfume was unfortunately discontinued by the Maison Givenchy (and I ask myself: Why?) but also because, changing my address and transporting too many objects, I didn't find anymore the precious 50ml bottle I owned and which was one of the last presents given to me by my mother for Christmas.
R.I.P. dear "Fleur d'interdit"...I'll smell you in my best dreams!

After repeated, but alas, unsuccessful attempts to find a single drop of well-preserved vintage, I have to say: "Goodbye, Dear Friend!" May you remain in my memory as young, fresh and beautiful, born for joy and seduction, as your creator intended you to be.

Apparently, you were too tender, time and conditions could not preserve your green and watermelon notes, some flowers in your heart have faded, sour shadows are imprinted on your profile and only the base reminds of what you were.

You've aged, we've aged, but it's a natural process, albeit a little sad.
You were unique, as evidenced by the lack of a large list of similar one. Your wonderful bottle I will tactilely remember always, in my memory you will forever be a favorite. And I will still look for you in new incarnations and hope that someday you will be re-released, rejuvenated and modernized.
Goodbye my beautiful, my Fleur d'Interdit!

Like Xeryus before it (also Givenchy) Fleur d’interdit is an odd mixture of styles.
It’s an aquatic - fruity-flora hybrid which re-jigs the classic feminine to appeal to under 25’s.
There is red fruity sweetness jostling with bitter moss and thin aquatic notes, and a sour woody musk coming from the base; three different tropes at loggerheads...
Needless to say, if you work on the principle of throwing enough muck at the fan - till some of it sticks - you won’t come up with a Jackson Pollock.

Today, on Christmas Eve, I am in a contemplative, yes somewhat sentimental mood, as so many dear people are no longer present for the family celebration.

They are in another place.

I have to come to terms with that - but I still miss them.
But my thoughts are with them.

I rummage through my scent memory box, which tells so many stories.
Christmas is the festival of love - and completely unexpectedly, a fragrance comes into my hands that has a lot to do with the theme of "love".

It is Fleur d`interdit by Givenchy.

I had already resignedly saved it under "Had I" - but it is indeed still there!

I wore it during the time when I fell in love with my husband, and he with me.
He is not a fragrance fan, but Fleur had captivated him - alongside my humble self.
This multifaceted scent underscored our getting to know each other until the wedding, like the film music of a romance.

The beautiful flower may be forbidden because it is so irresistibly attractive.
One cannot escape its charm, just as the sailors of the Loreley could not resist, and crashed their boats, intoxicated by the lovely song of the beauty.

Hyacinth, strawberry, and melon taste so sweet that one cannot get enough.
So it was with us - we had to always be together - and we still must.

Violet, rose, and lily of the valley are unabashedly romantic, but deep oak moss and dark iris admonish and warn.

Should one embark on the adventurous journey together - when one does not really know where it leads?
But do we have a choice?

I think of Erich Fried:
What it is

It is nonsense
says reason
It is what it is
says love

It is misfortune
says calculation
It is nothing but pain
says fear
It is hopeless
says insight
It is what it is
says love

It is ridiculous
says pride
It is reckless
says caution
It is impossible
says experience
It is what it is
says love

The forbidden flower has brought our souls together, and our little ship faithfully rocks through rough seas and calm waters.

Sometimes we land, sometimes we move on - but always the two of us.

The forbidden flower may possess magical power.

review_title: The Scent of My Elementary School Teacher *shudder*
review_content:
Some time ago, I wrote a blog post about scent memory. My example was Fleur d'Interdit. I assume my elementary school teacher wore it. This was in the mid-nineties, and back then, we still had somewhat rougher manners in elementary school, especially when the teacher - like my Mrs. F. - was tenured and couldn't be fired as long as she didn't hand out slaps. But otherwise, there weren't many limits to the cruelty. Luckily, she didn't have it out for me (thank goodness my mom sang in the same choir as her), but when I enthusiastically sprayed my Fleur s'Interdit that I had won on eBay a few years ago (I had no idea it smelled like Mrs. F., and I had completely forgotten about her), my hair stood on end. I spent about 20 minutes wondering why the scent was so unpleasant to me, and then it suddenly hit me like a ton of bricks. The teacher... And little Lisa in between, somewhere between fear and wanting to please, and aversion because she was always going after the best friend, who eventually broke down in tears, that wild boy, it was outrageous, and there was nothing to do but look down awkwardly and write his homework next time. That's Fleur d'Interdit.

SO unfortunate, because actually, it's so beautiful... As I already mentioned in my blog, I wore it quite often to drive away the unpleasant memories. And it works. Somewhere in the back of my mind, she still lurks, Mrs. F., but I can now enjoy the scent for what it is. A - now - completely out-of-fashion floral fragrance, lush, elegant, detail-oriented, like you can't find anymore today. Exactly my thing!

When spraying, there’s now a slightly sour note. My bottle must be about 25 years old, so it could very well be the signs of time. Looking at the top notes, that could fit as well. With melon, raspberry, wild strawberry, it can sometimes smell a bit sour, but the warmer it is, the less I perceive that. Even though Fleur d'Interdit is anything but a lightweight, it develops best in warm weather. I have the impression that the longer I wear the scent, the clearer the individual notes become. The flowers are expansive from the start. Lily of the valley, hyacinths, violets, lilacs... Everything grows wildly together. After about 3 hours, the fruit notes also become clearer. Strawberries, raspberries, with leaves in the sun. Green notes often seem cool and damp to me. That's not the case here. We definitely have green notes, but bright and sun-drenched. Really beautiful!

Fleur d'Interdit lasts effortlessly all day with strong sillage. Careful dosing is advisable, also because the scent is so out of sync with the current zeitgeist. It can happen that you stand out unpleasantly.

The base is rather inconspicuous, creeping in over time. Nice scratchy oak moss, cushioned by clean musk, slightly powdery, not really woody.

This one really takes off, and as is known with many high-quality vintage fragrances, the overall picture changes constantly, and the scent remains lively all day. I like it more and more the longer I wear it. I prefer it on really beautiful summer days when it's warm but with a light breeze. If you like this type of fragrance, grab a bottle somewhere. It's really worth it.

Fleur d'Interdit on my teacher was the first perfume I consciously noticed on someone, basically my prototype perfume. And I liked it a lot back then (Mrs. F. is mean, but she smells good). Now I'm very glad I kept the bottle and didn't sell it due to unpleasant memories. If you set those aside, it actually belongs to my all-time favorites.

review_title: Ming Shu and the Ming Dynasty...
review_content: ...have just as much to do with each other as Fleur d'Interdit and L'Interdit or a Chypre! Sure, the comparison is a bit off, but I did not choose it lightly. Fleur d'Interdit is - despite its large pyramid - not a Chypre and not a blockbuster (for Medusa: a bang *g*). I admit, I expected a kind of flanker to L'Interdit, but Fleur d'Interdit is not that either. In the...
